column54:
Almost everything that I experience and handle in my life , I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs supposed to be this difficult . 
Its been a while since i've realised and learnt that i'm a sensitive person . I've put limitations on myself so that i don't get affected much by people , circumstances and fear. So I‚Äôve been doing the same old safe common routine that suits me best . 
I haven't had much financial, social , parental or any kind of family dependency solely on me. But I want to take on more things in life now. I want to be responsible for more people ,causes and solutions possible. I want to do all this with absolute balance and no fear. Because I know i'm capable of doing a lot . But i'm not stretching myself enough . 
I'm 29 now, I want to go beyond just my set of family and friends. I want to make new connections confidently. 
For that I want to change myself. 
I want my mind to be at peace. I want to break free from any strong likes and dislikes that i've accumulated. I've managed to break free to an extent after Shambhavi, but I need to completely now. To accept people and situations as they are, without constantly believing in a strong sense of right or wrong judgement . 
Most importantly, I wish to be a happy and pleasant person for me and people around me , regardless of any external situations.
column55:
I used to be a professional tennis player and a trained carnatic singer. So i've always been in line with schedules and discipline since childhood. 
But the program goes a notch higher with the little personal time and away from home for a longer time than we did while playing in tournaments and camps . But all of it falls into the same category of what i'm working towards . Setting priorities straight. 
I think I could get overwhelmed initially, But i'll be able to get in tune with the rhythm of of the program in a few weeks .
column56: I walk almost everyday evenings for about 4 kms. Sitting in ardha siddhasana has been easy for me since the beginning of getting initiated into shambhavi, but the stamina to continue to sit for a long time is something that i'm trying to improve. Being in touch with soil, sun and plants is my most favorite space to be in . This combination is the main reason for my never missing walks at KBR national park everyday . Practicing surya kriya since few months has been helping me with building strength . I am going to get initiated into yogasanas this month and angamardhana later after i'm well in tuned with yogasanas , by completing mandala . By june 2025, hatha yoga practices would hopefully help me be well prepared with the physically strenuous activities like farming at ashram.
column57: I want to be that person who does any work , regardless of preference and skill , joyfully with complete involvement . This is one of the main reason's i am coming to sadhanapada .
column58:
I am looking forward to this. Because I think if you're person who can live and move in bare minimum, with just what is needed, , you will be able to live anywhere fearlessly regardless of any condition, without being captivated by the idea of comfort and luxury . 
I've always had a room of my own, or maybe shared for sometime with my sister . So until a situation is created where we have an opportunity to get in touch with shared spaces and different people with just required means, we can't really mould ourselves. 
Because in reality, a lot of energy is spent on where , how and whom we stay with and getting others help to clean our own space. If all these things are eradicated , I believe real necessary things will start happening .
column59:

In recent years, I have realised that I haven‚Äôt fully invested in myself, leaving me feeling lost in the monotony of work and unfulfillment. I often question the purpose behind what I do, which feels especially unsettling as a people leader. This lack of clarity has taken a toll, leaving me mentally exhausted, and a sense of unfulfillment. The emotional ups and downs I experience have made it clear that, to lead effectively, I need to cultivate inner stability and clarity about my path forward. It‚Äôs time to step back, reflect, and realign with what truly matters to me. 
 
By the end of the program, I feel I will break my limitations and be a stable and clear version of myself.

column54: Namaskaram, I did my graduation from a Vedic school and I always more keen about spiritual practices but the thing is nobody was actually teaching the spiritual process (like yoga & all)..and I am in a search of my guru, then I found Sadhguru, he helped me in my hard times, I cannot even explain how much he means to me..so I thought..in this society where so many ugly things are being done only for sake of the money..why I not chose to be a part of a foundation which means a lot to me and to people in transforming ones life...it's just overwhelming for me. And I love to be a part of isha more than anything..that's why I applied for samyama sadhana volunteering previously and done that.. and I also coming for volunteering for upcoming two samyama with Sadhguru programs and going to do my bsp in may..,and I want to deepen my sadhana because in this society one after another, there will be so many aspects that didn't necessarily be helpful for our sadhana, being in the ashram and depening my sadhana & exploring so many aspects in the lap of sadhguru, it means a lot to me...I just love it..I just love to be a part of sadhguru's vision..
column55: I am perfectly fine with it, like I said I am used to that kind of schedule..so I don't think it's a problem to me, but yes it's quite challenging for doing it consistently for 7 months..I think it's little overwhelming...but I love to take challenges...and it's for my own self..and also helping others always been a part of my life..it means. Tremendously big deal for me.. whenever I see someone struggling through their life I just want to reach out and help them but responding and acting are two different things but..if I get to help people in person in anyway that's possible ,I can do whatever that is needed for that...and I love to do volunteering.
column56: I am walking 7-8 kilometres a day and I am sitting 8-9 hours a day on the floor..and also I help my farm once in a while.. Yes those are quite challenging and physically demanding but I live for exploring every aspect of my life...i am just looking forward to it.
column57: Yes, i I know my capability's are going to be tested, I will do everything that I can do...I will give my best for everything..
column58: Even now I didn't have my own bedroom and all I am sleeping with my brother..but..Yes..sure..I used to that too...In my hostel I am living with 21 people in a room and have common bathrooms for 90 people...but yes it's perfectly fine for me ...and I can get along .. with people whatever they are..yes I am perfectly fine with sharing... because I am going for myself and also others are coming for theirs...

column54:
I have been an Isha devotee since 2012, and despite my busy schedule, I make it a point to watch at least one video every day. In November 2023, I had the privilege of completing the Inner Engineering program, and since then, practicing Shambhavi Mahamudra daily has not only transformed the trajectory of my life but has placed me on a completely different orbit. 
 
In addition, I am currently learning the Bhagavad Gita under the guidance of India‚Äôs top spiritual corporate trainer, Rohit Arora. This combination of spiritual practices has made me realize the importance of being guided by a Guru in order to reach a higher level of consciousness. I seek to experience sustained joy and blissfulness throughout the day, not just in fleeting moments. Through Sadhanapada, I hope to deepen my spiritual practices and integrate them into every aspect of my life, allowing for lasting inner transformation and a higher state of awareness."
column55:
My children admire my dedication and laser focus in anything I commit to, and I view the strict daily schedule as an opportunity to further discipline myself. While I may have very little personal time, I see this as a trade-off for elevating my consciousness, which will ultimately benefit not only me but also my family and everyone around me. 
 
I understand that this is not a corporate job where days off are expected; this journey is for my own personal and spiritual growth. Adhering to the program's requirements and the ashram‚Äôs guidelines will only strengthen my resolve and deepen my experience. I am excited to embrace ashram life for the next 7 months and the transformation it will bring."
column56:
On a lighter note, I often tell people that I‚Äôm mentally 25 and physically 67! Walking long distances shouldn't be an issue, as I already walk a minimum of 5,000 steps and up to 10,000 steps daily. I also love gardening, so farming feels like a natural extension of something I enjoy. 
 
The biggest challenge for me might be sitting cross-legged, but after inquiring, I was reassured that it will be addressed, and I‚Äôll receive guidance on how to manage it. I am confident I‚Äôll be able to adapt and meet the physical demands of the program."
column57:
At 67, I understand my physical limitations. Intense physical activities like carrying 25 kg provision bags for extended periods may be challenging for me, but tasks of lesser intensity should be manageable. I‚Äôm equally comfortable with office-based volunteering, as I enjoy interacting with people and learning from them. It also deepens my gratitude for all the blessings in my life. 
 
I am open to either a rotational system or a single volunteering assignment‚Äîwhatever the standard operating procedure is at the Isha Centre. I am ready to contribute in whatever capacity is needed."
column58:
Having spent 34 years in the merchant navy as a radio officer, I‚Äôve lived in the comfort of a spacious, private room with stewards at our service, experiencing the luxury side of life. However, I believe there can be a lot of fun and camaraderie in sharing a room, bathroom facilities, and volunteering activities‚Äîlike those memorable hostel scenes in movies set in engineering colleges! 
 
I am eagerly looking forward to this experience and the connections it will bring."
column59: "Initially, my family was hesitant, especially with my 7-month-old grandson, Aarvik, at home and my daughter and son-in-law both working. However, as they have seen my growing commitment to this journey, they are now fully supportive. They are eager for me to go to the Isha Yoga Center, believing that I will return refreshed, re-energized, and revitalized‚Äîready to share the experience and take them all to a higher level of consciousness."

column11: From June 2012 to September 2016, I served as Vice President of Quality Assurance & Training at Cawasji Beharamji Catering Services Ltd., overseeing a team of 800 employees. My responsibilities included managing Quality, Health, Safety, and Environmental (HSE) standards across operations. I was also responsible for delivering HSE Level 1, 2, and 3 training for offshore staff, as well as providing soft skills training for onshore personnel, ensuring a high standard of performance and safety in all aspects of the business."

"From 1977 to 2000, I worked as a Radio Officer in the Merchant Navy, responsible for maintaining communication between ships and shore stations, ensuring the safe transmission of critical information. I monitored and operated radio equipment, handled emergency communications, and ensured compliance with international maritime communication standards, contributing to the safety and efficiency of maritime operations."

From 2000 to 2006, I worked as a Base Station Radio Officer with Cairn Energy India Pvt Ltd, where I was responsible for managing communication systems between offshore and onshore operations. In addition to handling radio communications, I coordinated helicopter operations and liaised with various service vendors during exploration, drilling, and production phases. My role also extended to supporting warehousing, supply chain management, and logistics, ensuring smooth and efficient operations across multiple departments."

From 2006 to 2012, I worked as a Fleet Administration Officer with Shell International UK, assisting the ship's master with communication and ensuring the proper maintenance of all electronic equipment onboard. I was responsible for managing deck and engine stores, handling the inward and outward clearance of vessels for customs, immigration, quarantine, and agency matters. Additionally, oversaw food messing, including purchasing, menu setting, and managing the catering department staff to ensure high-quality service on board."

column54: I wish to go through Sadhanapada at this particular time because I feel an inner calling to prioritize my spiritual growth and well-being. Life has been filled with constant activity, and I recognize the need to step back, focus inward, and explore a deeper connection with myself and the universe. The structure and environment provided by Sadhanapada seem like the perfect opportunity for me to learn and practice the tools necessary for self-transformation.
column55:
I understand that following the strict daily schedule, having limited personal time, no days off, and strictly adhering to the program's requirements and ashram guidelines will require a high level of commitment and discipline. While this may seem challenging, I see it as a necessary part of the transformative process. 
 
I am willing to embrace this structure because I believe it will help me focus entirely on my spiritual growth and well-being, free from distractions. The discipline and routines will help me develop inner stability, clarity, and a deeper connection with the practices. I am also prepared to surrender to the ashram's way of life, trusting that this immersive experience is designed to help me break old habits and cultivate a stronger, more focused self
column56: I understand that the physical demands of the program, such as walking long distances, sitting cross-legged for extended periods, and engaging in challenging activities like farming, will test my endurance and adaptability. While I may not be fully accustomed to such demands, I see them as an essential aspect of the program that will contribute to my physical and mental growth.
column57: I am fully willing to be assigned to any kind of volunteering activity, whether it is physically intense or office-based, for the entire duration of the program. I see volunteering as an integral part of the Sadhanapada experience, helping me cultivate humility, selflessness, and a sense of service.
column58: I am comfortable with the idea of sharing space with other volunteers, including staying in a dormitory, using shared bathroom facilities, and working together during volunteering activities. I see this as an opportunity to cultivate a sense of community, cooperation, and understanding.
column59: My family is supportive of my decision to stay at the Isha Yoga Center for the full duration of the program. While they understand that it is a significant commitment, they see the value it can bring to my personal growth and overall well-being. They appreciate that this is an important step in my journey of self-transformation and are encouraging me to dedicate myself fully to the experience.

He is planning to quit from job. His notice period is 3 months, which is negotiable. 

He is planning to get married in April/May 2025. His fiancee has also applied for SP. Her name is Meenakshi Jain. When I asked what if one of them gets selected for SP this year, to which he said, they would be ok. Though they haven't discussed this scenario with parents. 

For expense, he said he has some savings but his family will also support him. 

His family was hesitant earlier & he mentioned they asked him lot of questions about SP. Also, they wanted to know what is the need for him to do it. When I asked about any dependencies on him in any ways, he mentioned that his mother prefers to talk to him daily. To which, when I asked if sometimes due to nature of the program, if he is not able to talk to his mother, then? To this, he said he is not sure of this & he has not spoken to his mother about this scenario. 

He has water balloon (cyst) in lower abdomen right side, which is painful sometimes. Doctor has suggested small surgery which is of 2 to 3 days. There are no restrictions as such for him to follow but he will check with his neurologist again about this. 
He also has varicocele Level 3 on left side (blood does not flow straight). There is no pain he feels so nothing needs to be done. He had a leg injury 3 years back, so due to less movement of leg, it is assumed he developed this condition. 
3 years back, when the train was about to halt, he got pushed due to crowd & he had ligament issue in his left leg. It took 1.5 years for it to heal. Due to this, he could not do SMMK. Now, he plays cricket, there is no problem with his leg or physical body.

Alcohol - Last he had in Dec 2024. Frequency is 5 times a year. No cig or drugs. 


Looking at all the above factors, according to me, he should come for Long Term Volunteering because he has done MSR Volunteering of only 15 days - with these medical conditions will he be able to sustain intensity for 7 months. Also, his marriage is happening just before SP.

column36: He has a strong desire to deepen his spiritual growth ‚úî Plus in a few years he is planning to raise a family with his current partner and soon he is expecting a promotion at work which will put him in charge of a team of five people ‚úî For all these reasons he feels the responsibility to become the best version of himself in order to take care and provide for others in the best possible way ‚úî Hence he wants to experience the safe space of the ashram, away form external influences, to break his limitations, his karma, his likes and dislikes and become a better person.
column46: General Volunteering (Dhyanalinga, Dining, Tree Care, Linga Bhairavi, Shivanga Store)
column54:
There are 3 main ambitions that drive me to participate in the Sadhanapada program and to complete it successfully now in 2025/2026 
| 1. Intensifying my own spiritual growth --> My focus in whatever I do each day is to bring balance to my system, establish clarity in my mind, being emotionally stable in whatever situation I‚Äôm in as well as becoming a more fully-fledged, intense and energetic human being. Especially after participating and volunteering for the BhavaSpandana program, I have wanted to expand my comfort zone until I break my limitations. Instead of earning a living, I work every day as a management consultant to confront myself in ever new situations with clients and being always on to enhance my awareness and to grow spiritually. Therefore, I feel a strong desire in myself to deepen my already regular Sadhana (1-2 times per day of Angamardana, Surya Shakti/Kriya, Shakti Chalana Kriya, Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya as well as 2 times per day of Shoonya) in a supportive space. While visiting the Ashram right now (12/2024), I sensed new dimensions offered by the consecrated spaces (Suryakund, Dhyanalinga, Bhairavi Devi, Naga and Adiyogi) and noticed that it had a significant impact on my Sadhana. I also felt a deep connection to the ashram in my 5 days of volunteering and I want to make this a fixed part of my daily structure and deepen my spiritual growth in the ever-changing situations to break my limitations. Becoming more robust and healthy, peaceful and joyful, loving and compassionate, blissful and ecstatic might be a consequence of the Sadhanapada program. My focus is on going through the process of cracking my Karma. 
| 2. Become a better version of myself to enhance my impact towards a sustainable economy => I work for a German management consulting firm (similar to McKinsey, BCG, Bain) with 1,400 employees. My focus is on making companies ready for Environmental, Social & Governance (ESG) reporting , developing sustainability strategies integrated into the corporate strategy and establishing the corresponding ESG performance management. 
| 2.1 Become a better version of myself to acquire and deliver impactful sustainability projects => On the one hand, I want to develop high-impact solutions together with our clients so that they can transform their business models towards a sustainable economy. This means reducing their own negative impact on the environment (greenhouse gas emissions, pollution of soil, water and air, biodiversity, exploitation of workers in the value chain, bribery, etc.) as well as defining profound measures to mitigate long-term risks and to benefit from long-term opportunities. Especially our German clients should utilise sustainability knowledge, develop and implement actions and technologies as well as play a pioneering role to take action against the global impact of climate change, resource use, soil pollution and the social consequences of these and the global economic system. For my consulting activities and project acquisition, I have to be the best version of myself in order to convince and inspire clients and achieve real sustainable impact instead of just reaching project sales targets (earning a living). 
| 2.2 Become a better version of myself to be a compassionate, supportive and empowering leader => Although our management consulting firm plays a purpose-driven and proactive role in our client projects, our leadership approach is traditionally driven by financial targets, KPI measurement and incentive schemes. This leads to a lot of pressure both for senior colleagues to achieve their sales targets and tight project management as well as to work overload for junior colleagues in delivering projects. This damages the psychological security of our young colleagues, with the result that many have already resigned because they have to compromise their purpose for sustainability with economic interests of the leadership team. I therefore want to be the best version of myself in order to offer my future mentees/employees a safe space in which they can live out their sustainability ambitions, feel seen in their challenges, receive helpful support, having a clear guidance, realise their potential and develop themselves further as conscious human beings instead of turning towards being driven by their financial incentives. 
| 3 Becoming a better version of myself for my future family => My inner desire for spiritual growth (see section 1) drives me to break my own limitations from my upbringing, socialisation and previous life experiences in such a way that I can be a father to my future children who is lovingly supporting them in their physical, mental, emotional and spiritual development, so that they can become fully-fledged human beings. This includes contributing to a healthy, peaceful and joyful, loving and compassionate, blissful and ecstatic environment for my girlfriend (future wife), my children and the wider family. I want to offer my family the stability, unconditional acceptance and love they need to develop freely and flexibly and to face every situation in life with an open heart and mind and to perceive ‚Äúfailure‚Äù as a new opportunity to learn and handle life differently. In this context, I would also like to be a helpful support to my girlfriend (future wife) in all the challenges she faces as a mother and encourage and empower her to be the best version of herself in order to support the children in their development. For me, being the best version of myself also means being an example for a spiritual life and showing my children that spiritual tools can be an enrichment for their own lives. I want my children to see an authentic father with a peaceful, joyful, loving, compassionate, blissful and ecstatic face so that they can develop and realise these qualities in their own lives. 
||| To summarise my 3 ambitions: for me it is now the right time to deepen my spiritual growth and develop myself into a fully-fledged human being to intensify my qualities and taking responsibility for everything in my own life as well as being prepared for taking responsibilities for the life of others such as my future mentees/employees and my future family.
column55: I understand following strict daily schedule, having very little personal time, no days off as well as strictly adhering to the requirements and expectations of the program along with the guidelines of staying in the ashram at first as overwhelming but in the end as a great support system. Strict daily schedule allocates the necessary time for Sadhana, seva, staying in consecrated places, 2x meals a day, Sadhguru darshan, rest at night etc. in order to align all the respective activities (for every participant). It offers isolation from the outside world in order to focus on my own Sadhana and tools given by Sadhguru. It also fosters a safe space to break out of familiar structures and tendencies that would be automatically triggered in familiar surroundings or during personal time. The strict daily schedule for 24/7 enables me to establish a continuous rhythm for an always-on state of energy and intensity. All this allows each participant the potential to make the same deep experiences within the Sadhanapada program. It also preserves the spiritual and supportive atmosphere and confidentiality of the ashram
column56: I had consciously decided to learn Angamardana to improve my physical fitness and to have a balance from my daily office work. The intensive physical work in the Sadhanapada program helps to consciously shift attention from thoughts in the mind continuously to the body and the life process. It strengthens the awareness of consciously using the body, expanding its resilience, transcending boundaries and breaking the body's limitations. That's why I really appreciated volunteering in the garden or at Bhiksha Hallo during my stay in the ashram. This also applies to sitting cross-legged to increase flexibility in the legs and have more energy available for the upper body. The high level of physical activity in the Sadhanapada program will help to stabilise the body and mental strength, even if it is challenging.
column57: I am willing to accept the volunteering activities as they are assigned to me, regardless of my likes and dislikes. I already try to approach every upcoming situation with an open heart and mind when volunteering at my local center or on Isha programmes as well as when working on new client projects. It is therefore my ambition in the Sadhanapada program to use the volunteering activities assigned to me to deepen my inner experience, to respond consciously to unexpected situations and to break my limitations.
column58: While I was at the ashram, long-term volunteers showed me the dormitory accomodation for 25 people, the shared bathroom facilities and washing areas for a first impression. I also had an insight into being together with many volunteers in a small shared space while gardening, in the Bhisksha Hall and in the Bhairavi temple. I found shared dormitories in hostels for up to 20 people and shared rooms during program volunteering to be team-building after a certain adjustment period. In this context, I see the many shared spaces as an opportunity to make Sadhanapada an experience for all participants.
column59: My girlfriend is very supportive of my desire to join the Sadhanapada program in 2025/2026. She has already completed Inner Engineering and practices Angamardana and Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya daily. From her own positive experience, she understands my desire to grow spiritually and is willing to let me go to the ashram for 7 to 9 months, including the reduction of our communication for that period of time. My father and mother also support my wish to participate in the Sadhanapada program. From their Christian background, they understand my spiritual ambitions. Even though they have no connection to yoga, spiritual growth, Sadhguru and a life in an Indian ashram, they support my path. As my parents and I have an unattached relationship, they know that as an independent child they have to let me dispose of my life freely. My closest friends support my aspiration to join the Sadhanapada program as they have noticed a very positive development in me since I completed Inner Engineering and since I have been practising Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya regularly. Even my employer supports me doing the Sadhanapada program as part of a sabbatical to foster my personal growth.
column60:
I used my time in the ashram as a cottage guest and as a volunteer in the Gardening, Dining and Linga Bhairavi temple to gain insights into the life during the 7-9 months of the Sadhanapada program and to visualise it realistically for myself instead of making naive assumptions. 
I feel a strong desire to do Sadhanapada in 2025/2026 . After being rejected in the application last year, I have volunteered a lot to deepen my experience and break na√Øve ideas of Sadhanapada. I want to do Sadhanapada in 2025/2026 and it's the right time for me. I am free of obligations (caring for relatives, property and financial commitments, etc.). I am in a stable relationship with my girlfriend, who will also cope with the 7 to 9 months distance well. I want to do Sadhanapada before planning a family and before taking the next steps in my career. Sadhanapada is a prerequisite for me to take these forward-looking decisions in my life. 
What does it take for me to get accepted?

column54:
I have been mentally and socially preparing to have this opportunity for quite some time now. I am a serving Army officer and am taking voluntary retirement in Jan 2025 with full consent of my family. After my retirement, I wish to go through this program as the first thing to reflect on my life and get clarity. I have done my Inner Engineering in 2019 and a regular practitioner of Shamvabi Maha mudra. Now, I wish to to deepen my Sadhana in the sacred space of Ashram. deeper for a protracted period of time which i think is an opportunity of several lifetimes. I have taken care of my filial and financial commitments. Hopefully , our only child will get admission in Residential school next academic session. So , I think this is most appropriate time in my life to go for such inner experience. Moreover, I am a proud bharatiya and practising Hindu who want to lead a life of dharma and seeking as Sadhguru exhorts. However , I don't think that I have had any profound training to lead such a life. I strongly believe that Sadhanapada will provide the opportunity to strengthen my Spiritual seeking . I am 43 years old and can't wait more. 
 
Through the program, I want to deepen my Sadhana, get profound clarity within self and bring Consciousness in thoughts and deeds. I want to understand and experience the profound foundation of Sanatana Dharma , Yoga and Bharatiya Civilisation & culture through this process.
column55: I am looking for inner transformation and clarity. That's not a small expectation. I am fully aware that anything profound in life can only be achieved with resolute focus, discipline and commitment. Hence , I am not surprised. I will prepare myself fully before coming to the program.

column36: She wants to go the root of her life - find her purpose instead of going back to the hamster wheel. Already took a break of 7 months (unpaid leave) and went on pilgrimages, did a ttc in Nepal for about 2 months or so and now she has re-joined in IT. So she plans to quit next year and take time to just be in such a space with like minded people that help her deepen her spiritual practices. So SP will be good for her to focus on her inner growth and volunteering work.
column54: After 7 months off from work in 2024 and back to work, I saw myself confronted with the dullness of everyday life, old habbits and stress and a lack of motivation because of a still missing purpose. With reminding myself of finding my purpose and my willingness of learning, exploring and being open to life, I knew the time had come for a bigger decision to start a real change in my life to coming closer to a life with purpose. So, lately, I have decided to get rid of many attachments, moved into a refurbished small flat until May/June 2025, got rid of so many belongings to break free and to be free for a longer spiritual journey and volunteering work to India, Nepal and other countries. When a friend told me about the Sadhanapada, it felt like the perfect opportunity and time during this stage of my life. I would love to grow in my discipline, spiritual practice, get rid of not useful material and social attachments and to offer my time and energy for a purposeful project with likeminded people.

On the other side, I also experienced that the mind and body is flexilble and able to adapt to new environments step by step and that I can rely on me.

column54:
Namaskaram. 
First of all, awfully sorry for the late completion of this reflection form. Both emails with the link landed in my spam folder. I was just going to email the Sadhanapada support to see what the next step is when my wife suggested to check the spam folder and we noticed these email. 
 
If I would try to paint a picture about why I wish to go through Sadhanapada in one sentence, it would be: "Because I feel a calling towards it". 
My main goal is to break my old patterns to jump start my personal growth further. Lately, it feels to me like every year is like a loop. Most of the time, I am very focused on my practices and inner growth (because I have less distractions), but for certain periods my focus decreases. I do my practices every day, but I feel like my awareness is not the same. I would like to improve this so that my focus is on 100%, all the time, regardless of the exterior conditions and distractions. 
I have also wanted to spend an extended period of time in the Ashram since the first time I visited (Jan 2020). Starting with the Isha practices increased the quality of my life significantly, so I have amazing respect for Sadhguru, the Ashram and the volunteering work behind making all of this possible. 
Sadhanapada feels like to perfect opportunity to do so.
column55: I like waking up early and having structure in my days. I see this as an opportunity to fully focus on the daily activities and increase my awareness.

column57: I have actually wanted to be more involved in volunteering work since the first time I visited the Ashram in Jan 2020. I see Sadhanapada as an opportunity for this. I am fully open to embrace any activity that I will be given.
column58:
I am more than willing to share my space. I am used to it since I did this on multiple occasions in my life (for yoga programs, with team mates when I played sports, with friends, family etc.) 
I do want to mention that my wife is also applying for Sadhanapada, so if we both get accepted and if there is the possibility to do so, it would be nice to be able to share the space with her and support each other.
column59: My family supports me fully. They have noticed the changes in my life since I started the Isha practices, 6 years ago. This actually led to my sister and father to attend Inner Engineering as well, so they have felt the benefits in person.

Thank you! Have an amazing day!

column54:
At this particular time, I feel deeply that Sadhanapada is the right step for me because I have been working on my spiritual path for several years, and now I sense the need for a shift‚Äîa way to break out of the repetitive patterns I find myself in. Life, as it is, seems to cycle through similar experiences, and I feel ready to break free from this loop and explore a fresh perspective. This program feels like an opportunity to start anew, to immerse myself completely in a transformative experience that not only deepens my spiritual journey but also brings clarity and renewal. 
 
Volunteering has always been a dream of mine, and I see Sadhanapada as the perfect space to serve selflessly while also growing inwardly. At 30 years old, I feel this is the right time to commit to something meaningful, something that resonates with both my inner aspirations and my desire to contribute positively to the world. Through this program, I hope to cultivate discipline, gain insights, and align myself with a life of balance, purpose, and deeper connection.
column55: I understand and accept this. These structures are designed to cultivate discipline, focus, and an immersive experience that aligns with the program's purpose. Living within the ashram's guidelines and adhering to its expectations is something I am ready for, as I see it as an essential step in shedding old patterns and embracing a more focused and purposeful way of living. I view them as opportunities to grow and to deepen my commitment.
column56: I am actually really excited about the physical demands of the program. I see these tasks not as challenges but as opportunities to reconnect with my body, strengthen it, and enhance my physical endurance. It‚Äôs something I truly look forward to‚Äîbeing active, using my body in different ways. These physical activities will not only support my overall well-being but also help me stay present and grounded in the moment, contributing to my transformation.
column57: I trust that whatever seva is offered to me will be exactly what I need to do, and I am ready to embrace it with an open heart. I understand that each task, no matter how challenging or different from what I know, will contribute to my growth and transformation. I am committed to serving with dedication and am confident that the experience will be valuable, whatever form it takes, without setting expectations.
column58:
I am comfortable with sharing space with other volunteers, whether in a dormitory, using shared bathroom facilities, or during group activities. I‚Äôve already experienced this during my previous visits to the ashram, and it was a positive and enriching experience. I understand that communal living fosters connection and unity, and I am fully prepared for it. 
 
I am signing up with my husband for the Sadhanapada program, and we are also planning to do the Vivaha ceremony. I wanted to share this, as I am confident that all the activities will be part of our journey together, as separate individuals and will enhance our family life as well.

column54: I am at a point in my life where I seek clarity and direction for the next phase. Through the Sadhanapada program, I am hoping to cultivate greater discipline in my daily life and deepen my sadhana. This program offers me the opportunity to evaluate whether I can fully dedicate myself to Sadhguru‚Äôs teachings and live in alignment with his vision. I hope to develop a stronger sense of purpose and self-awareness as I step into this new chapter of life. I feel like this program will help me assess if I am ready to fully embrace this path or if I still need to work on certain aspects of myself to be prepared for such a commitment.
column55: I view this as a chance to fully immerse myself in the program and see if I can truly commit in the way that is expected. The strict schedule, minimal personal time, and the absence of breaks are all challenges, but I believe they are necessary for me to break through my limitations and grow. This structure will force me to confront my own resistance and discomfort, and I am ready to face that head-on. It‚Äôs not just about seeing if I can follow a routine. It‚Äôs about testing my ability to surrender completely, to give myself fully to the process, and to dedicate myself to something greater than my personal needs or comforts. I know it won‚Äôt be easy, but I‚Äôm prepared to dive in, to see if I can live up to the commitment, and to experience if this path truly aligns with who I am meant to become.
column56: This is exactly why I‚Äôm applying to push myself beyond my comfort zone, develop discipline, and experience growth through challenging physical tasks. Walking long distances, sitting cross-legged for extended periods, and engaging in physically demanding activities like farming will not be easy, but I am ready to face them. I understand that every task, no matter how difficult, is part of something much larger. By committing to these physical demands, I will not only strengthen my body but also deepen my sense of purpose, knowing that I am contributing to something greater than myself. I‚Äôm ready to surrender to the discomfort, because I know it‚Äôs essential for my transformation and growth.
column57: I‚Äôm fully willing to take on any volunteering activity, whether it‚Äôs physically intense or office-based. I wish to go through sadhanapada at this particular time because I have completed my inner engineering this year April 2024 online and got to know the taste of spirituality and importance of Sadhana. I wish to intensify my Sadhana without any distractions. As a working professional and living at home, I go through alot of distractions. 
 
Also, I started volunteering at local centre for every monthly satsang from May 2024. I had involved in all the activities for setting up the hall for monthly satsang. I have volunteered for Isha Gramotsavam 2024 at our place for backend support, registrations, etc. In the process of volunteering, it really helped me to understand how does it feels to be a volunteer. So, wanted to be part of Sadhguru vision and help in whatever way I can by means of volunteering in sadhanapada. 
 
I hope to grow through the program is 
1. Become open through seva. 
2.Intensify my Sadhana. 
3.Discipline. 
4.living in consecrated spaces. 
5.Work ethics. 
6.learn to Being ON all the time. 
7.make every activity as sadhana.

column10: Small Business Owner and Deafhood Yoga Teacher
column11: Daily operations of small business teaching yoga in sign language to Deaf people, worldwide, online and in person. To elevate human consciousness with whole health and language deprivation. Implementing the daily life experiences of Deaf people known as Deafhood with yoga. Marketing, communication and scheduling courses/programs. Development of Curriculums covering fields of Pranayama/Breathing, Relaxation, Movement, Lifestyle, and Meditation teaching the full circle of life with Deaf communities, meaning all ages. Also developed a Deaf Education: Yoga K-12 Curriculum. Provide services through camps, conferences, communities and more. Contract work with Universities, States, and private organizations. Trained and teach Prenatal Yoga, Children's Yoga, Adults, and Elders/Senior Citizens. Content provider for our website, app, and Learning Management System (LMS). Implementing and honoring the ancient roots of yoga from India with ongoing practice with yoga especially in Coimbatore, South India. Working with the Isha Yoga Center Ashram to teach yoga to Deaf Indian people in Indian Sign Language (ISL).
column18: Deaf Education: Family Centered Early Education Family Centered Early Education

column47: Laundromat: assisted with folding and washing sheets
column54: Being at the Isha Yoga Center (IYC) Ashram in Coimbatore, South India, to participate in Sadhanapada is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. The consecrated space offers profound support for my ongoing inner growth and spiritual evolution. One aspect I hope to refine is simplifying the way I express myself, particularly by using fewer words to communicate more effectively. This program is also a blessed opportunity for me to contribute to one of my beloved homes, IYC, and to share this experience, especially with the Deaf Akkas and Annas of India, by making it accessible in Indian Sign Language (ISL).
column55: It is always a profound delight to be at the ashram and immerse myself in its schedule, as it deeply nurtures and supports my entire being. While the absence of days off may present its challenges, I embrace it with the awareness that this phase is only temporary. I trust in the unwavering support of the ashram‚Äôs environment to help us navigate and grow through such moments with grace.
column56: Walking long distances has never been an issue for me because I genuinely love walking. For instance, I once participated in a community walk from San Francisco to Los Angeles, California, USA, to raise awareness about Sign Language. Currently, without access to a car, I walk an average of 4 to 7 miles almost every day. Sitting cross-legged comes naturally to me and is something my body enjoys, with gratitude to yoga practice. However, my right knee has felt tight recently, and I am actively working on its recovery. Farming and gardening were among my Seva activities at another yoga ashram of a different yoga lineage, which I deeply cherished as they allowed me to connect with Mother Nature in a meaningful way.
column57: I am willing and also wholeheartedly devoted to bringing an additional focus to serving our Deaf Indian communities by sharing the IYC ashram experience through Indian Sign Language (ISL).
column58: Not an issue. Know it is only temporary.
column59: Deeply in awe and wholeheartedly supportive.
column60: Maa Dakshina of the IPA Department has encouraged me to apply to this program. When I was at IYC last Summer, she connected me with Adharsh of the Sadhanapada Department to discuss this. Adharsh and I met last September right before I departed IYC. He is aware of our questions and discussion about if I am able to apply some of the Seva towards serving the Deaf Indian communities in Indian Sign Language (ISL). Our Deaf Akkas and Annas of India are truly hungry to experience, have access and be inclusive at the IYC Ashram. Adharsh informed me that he would check with his team and get back to me, which has not happened yet. Hopefully this will be an opportunity to follow up on that discussion.

column9: Hawai'i School for the Deaf and Blind
column11: Developed a Deaf Education: Yoga K-12 Curriculum. Taught this with the Deaf Middle School students. Overseed the progress from the beginning, middle, to the end of the semester. Studies showed that the practice of yoga in the school environment improved their academic performances, bullying issues and increase in self esteem. We recently moved back to this area and this school has asked for my return to teach yoga there again. Paperwork currently processing. Plan on updating this curriculum with the foundation of Isha Hatha Yoga practices.

At the Concord Store, handled the front floor and inventory of the outdoor gear. At the San Francisco store, handled the front floor and inventory of the outdoor clothes. Assisted with customer support when needed.

column9: Aspen Camp School for the Deaf
column11: Everything. Even lived onsite. Curriculum and program development. Operation of Summer and Winter Camps. Development of new programs that included the local communities and schools during the Fall and Spring at the camp. Implemented more Deaf Education and Awareness by coordinating community events. Communication, marketing, and recruitment of campers and seasonal staff. Communication with parents. Paperwork and office work. Traveled to promote the camp. Interview, hire, and train seasonal staff. Back up nurse, when needed. Van driver, when needed. Clean the camp bathrooms, showers, and cabins when needed. Back up cook and clean kitchen, when needed. Shovel trails in the snow when needed. Improve walking trails. Inventory of everything at the camp. Intensive clean around camp. Oversee camp store. Worked with the Director, and Board of Trustees on fundraising events. Support the scholarship process. Attended trainings to improve programs at the camp. Part of the team when built a new zip line course. Ensure that every person has a positive experience at the Aspen Camp School for the Deaf.

column9: California School for the Deaf, Fremont
column11: Worked with co-teacher to implement the Deaf Education curriculum with our Deaf Pre-Kindergarten students and families. Planned daily activities for the week, month, and school year. Encouraged and documented students progress in every area from the beginning, middle, to the school year. Areas include: language, reading, writing, math, science and more through hands on activities. Coordinated co-learning activities with the Kindergarten students to prepare our Pre-K students to transit next year. Coordinated community field trips. Supported Deaf students and families through their Individualized Education Program (IEP)s. Taught with so much love, joy, and laughter.

As well as their application filling out process. Worked with students to identify their interests and how to get there, career-wise.

column54: I often struggle to decide what type of life I should lead‚Äîwhether to chase my ambitions or embrace a simple lifestyle. Another challenge I face is self-care, as I lack the discipline to prioritize my health, despite understanding its importance. Through this program, I aim to develop the discipline to make my health a top priority, gain clarity in my thoughts and overall emotional balance within me , and determine the right path for my life, ultimately growing into a better version of myself.
column55: I feel a bit scared and nervous, wondering if I‚Äôll be able to complete this journey. While the intensity of the schedule and the unfamiliar environment make me apprehensive, I am confident that with determination and the support of the program's structure and community, I can rise to the occasion. I look forward to cultivating discipline, building resilience, and discovering my true potential through Sadhanapada

column57: I am open to being assigned to any kind of volunteering activity, whether physically intense or office-based, for the full duration of the program. column58:
Growing up, I have always shared my space with siblings, family, friends, and now my husband, so I am accustomed to shared living arrangements. I also understand the limitations and challenges that come with shared spaces, such as dormitories and bathrooms. I am prepared to follow all rules and regulations to ensure a harmonious environment. 
 
Additionally, I see this as an opportunity to cultivate patience, adaptability, and mutual respect, which are essential for community living. Sharing space during volunteering activities can foster a sense of teamwork and collective purpose, allowing me to grow personally while contributing to the larger goals of Sadhanapada

There are many reasons to go through Sadhanapada: 
1) I want to make my sadhana more intense. 
2) I feel like this is the time to give myself fully for volunteering & sadhana when I have the necessary energy and time and break my limitations & patterns. 
3) I have been doing my practices regularly but still external situations & environment affects me. I have experienced something beyond these situations & I wish to learn to be in that state. 
4) I want to learn to live a life beyond insecurities & fears. 
I am willing to give myself fully to the program and to just take it as it is whatever is offered to me & do everything which contributes to my inner growth.

column25:
1. Basic Computer Literacy 
Operating systems: Familiarity with Windows, macOS, or Linux. 
File management: Organizing, saving, and finding files using folders and directories. 
Keyboard shortcuts: Using shortcuts for efficiency (e.g., Ctrl+C for copy, Ctrl+V for paste). 
2. Word Processing 
Proficiency in Microsoft Word, Google Docs, or similar programs for creating, editing, and formatting documents. 
Ability to use features like tables, headers/footers, and text formatting tools. 
3. Spreadsheets 
Understanding of Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets for data entry, creating formulas, generating charts, and analyzing data. 
Knowledge of basic functions like SUM, AVERAGE, VLOOKUP, and PivotTables. 
4. Email and Communication Tools 
Using email clients (Outlook, Gmail) for effective communication and file sharing. 
Familiarity with scheduling tools like Google Calendar, Microsoft Outlook, or Zoom for meetings. 
5. Internet Skills 
Navigating web browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari) and performing searches using search engines. 
Knowledge of online safety practices, including recognizing phishing scams and using strong passwords. 
6. Presentation Software 
Creating presentations with Microsoft PowerPoint, Google Slides, or similar tools. 
Understanding of visual design principles for clear, engaging presentations (e.g., using appropriate fonts, colors, and layouts). 
7. Social Media and Collaboration Tools 
Basic knowledge of platforms like LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram. 
Familiarity with collaboration tools like Slack, Trello, or Asana for team projects and communication. 
8. Basic Troubleshooting and Maintenance 
Ability to solve simple technical problems like software errors, slow performance, and network issues. 
Knowledge of antivirus software and how to maintain system security. 
9. Cloud Storage and File Sharing 
Familiarity with cloud storage platforms like Google Drive, Dropbox, or OneDrive for storing, sharing, and collaborating on files.

column54:
I would say that the decision to undertake Sadhnapada is deeply personal one and it has stem from a genuine longing to delve deeper into my own existence . I wish to go through sadhnapada at this perticular time as I feel a strong pull towards selfie transformation. I have reached a point in my life where I am questioning the nature of my own existence ,my purpose and the true meaning of happiness and fulfilment . I seek a deeper connection with the world around , beyond the superficialities of life . 
 
Through Sadhanapada I hope to grow in several ways . 
1. Cultivate a deeper sense of inner peace and clarity . 
2. To enhance my physical and mental well being . 
3 . To Exprience oneness with universe through practice of yoga and meditation . 
4. To establish my self in Sadhna 
5. To live life consciously with awareness and joy .

column55: I have experienced the strict daily schedule, with little personal time for limited periods during my academics and work, but doing this for an extended period of 8 months will require openness during the initial month for getting accustomed. No days off is a first for me, this will definitely force me to live every moment since there's no separate time for that. I feel the requirements, expectations and guidelines are fair and can be adhered to strictly. Wishing that the regular sadhana will help me cope up with the changes and I can start preparing for the same. I have also experienced similar schedules when volunteering at Sadhguru Sannidhi although that is for a short period.
column56: I have lived in large campuses during my academics where it was required to walk kms just to get to one class then to the other following a fixed shedule. That requires planning time efficiently and managing expectations with stakeholders. I have been practicing sitting cross-legged for 20 min sukh kriyas thrice a day, eating by sitting down for Samyama for less than a month now, hope I can increase the kriya time. I have volunteered for shifting saplings in the nursery at Sannidhi for an entire day, the farming activity can be physically demanding, which needs getting used to.
column57: I like physically intense work, feels tiring and good by the end of the day. I am already used to office based work for 5-6 days in a week. The challenge for me will be working on the same task without breaks or weekend offs, but I should be able to adjust to that over time. If there's facility to switch tasks for some periods that might be helpful.

column55:
1) Strict daily schedule is what I am looking for to discipline myself in whatever I might do right from the time I wake up. 
2) Little personal time gives one the opportunity to be aware of self at all times and also reflect on what is done. 
3) After doing one simple practice of angamardana I am filled with energy so much that I lose track of hours and days too, now at the ashram with regular sadhana I am sure the energy levels will be high and the sleep quota will go down. With this combination I did utilize it seva than taking a day off. 
4) strictly adhering to the requirements is the only way to get the most from this program or else it will be no different than my home environment. 
5) Staying at ashram is the best thing about the program as the place itself helps one in completing the program successfully.

In my life to engage deeply with a program like Sadhanapada, as y 
 at a formative age 20 -21 and aiming to build a strong foundation for personal and professional life. I seeing Sadhanapada as a unique opportunity to cultivate qualities time that will help to become the best version of myself. 
 
I desire to do this before enter a more conventional work path shows that you value the kind of inner and outer discipline that such an environment can offer. Being able to do Sadhana in a dedicated, supportive space like Isha allows me to fully immerse self in growth, something that might be harder to pursue once you start a career. 
 
Also, aligning has CMA inter student professional aspirations with the volunteering seva there speaks to MY openness to learn accounting, auditing, costing, management skills and gain hands-on experience in an environment that reflects values. The mix of inner work and practical experience could be an ideal way to prepare myself both spiritually and professionally.

column36: She visited ashram during MSR.During that time she fell in love with the ashram ambience , fellow volunteers were like family for her.She feels that her inner child died due to the way she was living (studies , stress etc) and shambhavi reignited that for her.She wants to do intensify her sadhana as it used to.
column54: Ever since I set foot in the ashram earlier this year for MSR event, I was drawn very deeply to the energy of the place. It was a dream come true to finally make it to ISHA. And also fortunately I was able to see Sadhguru in person for the first time. Tears would flow from my eyes out of nowhere when I saw him. He has touched my life in ways I am very grateful for. During my stay, I developed a special friendship with some Sadhanapada participants and they would tell me how transformed their lives were because of the program. They would get emotional as their days in the ashram were numbered and they encouraged me to apply for the program. By then, I had already made up my mind that after my PhD was over, I would apply. My PhD is at its final stage now. Besides the encouragement from them, I have always wanted to stay in the ashram and lead the life of a spiritual seeker doing my sadhana and also offering seva. My share of suffering in life has led me to the path of spirituality. I am very blessed to exist in the same time as Sadhguru, listening to him has brought me such calmness and confidence. It felt like he was the only person who understood me, and I also understood him so effortlessly. Through Sadhanapada, I wish to grow spiritually as an individual and also grow as part of a community through seva. I want to stretch the limit in me, surprise myself by tapping into the potential that buried deep within me. I want to say yes to the adventure with a big smile and surrender to what ever the program has to offer because I have realised, good or bad, it is for my ultimate growth!

column54:
I wish to go through the Sadhanapada program as I have seen the tremendous benefits of yoga and meditation and want to further enhance my experience. Growing up, I wanted to be a professional tennis player and thus started doing yoga when I was 13 years old for its physical benefits. However, I quickly realized that yoga was not only helping my body but also my mind. I felt more calm, centered and focused on the tennis court and there was a notable improvement in my performance as well. 
 
When I was 15, I started to struggle with anxiety but instead of turning to medication, I began doing even more breathing and yoga. Not only did the yoga help me overcome the anxiety, but I noticed that the deeper I went into my practices, the more the quality of my life improved. I started following Sadhguru and doing Isha practices in the summer of 2020 and now having done Inner Engineering, Bhava Spandana, and Hatha Yoga, I see a world of difference in myself. I am much more conscious, focused, grateful, and joyful and am keen to enhance my experience even further at the ashram. 
 
In terms of the timing, I actually applied and was accepted for Sadhanapada starting in July 2023, which was just after I graduated from university. However, I was also selected for a highly competitive two year fellowship program at the United States Department of Treasury in Washington D.C. and was not able to postpone the start date. It was a tough decision but I ultimately decided to do the Treasury fellowship as it was a unique opportunity to gain exposure to the highest levels of government straight out of college. The fellowship program has a two year limit so it was always my intention to apply for Sadhanapada again once my time was up. 
 
If I am accepted, I feel that it would be a good time for me to go through Sadhanapada. I have been working for close to a year and a half at this point and I am thus able to see what my limitations are and I want to overcome them. By the end of the Sadhanapada, I hope to be less compulsive, more energetic, have greater clarity of thought, and feel more comfortable with myself. The prospect of deepening my current practices, learning new practices and volunteering everyday intuitively feels like the right next step for me.
column55:
I think that whilst it may initially be challenging to adjust to the requirements and expectations of the program, I will eventually get used to it. As I mentioned above, I wanted to be a professional tennis player growing up and represented the South African junior team in international competitions. My desire to improve and passion for the sport motivated me to start living a highly disciplined life as a teenager. I trained for 4-5 hours a day whilst continuing to study hard and keep up good grades at school. 
 
During my time at university and now as a working adult, I have continued to live a disciplined life as I have seen its immense benefits and the happiness that it gives me. I am conscious about what I eat, I am highly focused continuously trying to improve at my job, and I do my yoga practices everyday, no matter what is happening around me. Overall, whilst it might take some time to adjust to the strict schedule and rules of ashram, I think that I will be able to adapt as I have been in similarly intense environments before and understand that it is what is needed to break one‚Äôs limitations. I know that if I am able to go through a program as intense as Sadhanapada, it will make me feel more capable of handling anything that may come up in my life.
column56: I am comfortable with the physical demands of the program. Even though I am no longer pursuing tennis professionally, I am still very active. I bike, run, swim, walk, lift weights and do hatha yoga on a weekly basis as well as continue to play tennis recreationally. I really enjoy being active and find that it helps both my body and my mind.
column57: I am happy to be assigned with any kind of volunteering activity for the full duration of the program. Due to my experience with tennis and the active lifestyle that I lead, I am comfortable with physically intense activities. I am also comfortable with extended periods of office work as that is essentially what I do now. I am at the office for between 8-10 hours a day during the week.
column58: I am happy to share my space with many other volunteers and have had the experience many times before. I always shared a room with my teammates when I travelled for tennis and I lived in a shared dorm for my first two years of university and in a shared apartment for the remainder of the time. I have never had issues with my roommates and the only hesitation that I have ever had about sharing is not having a private space to do my yoga practices. Obviously, this will not be a problem at Isha!
column59: My family is supportive of me staying at the Isha Yoga Center for the full duration of the program. My father is an Isha meditator and he was actually the first person that suggested Sadhanapada to me. The rest of my family are also supportive as they have seen how much yoga has benefitted me and also helped improve my relationship others. They are all proud of me for wanting to take this next step and are motivated to do some Isha programs themselves.

column54:
Namaskaram. I sense that everything I have experienced so far in this lifetime has led me to this point. Every participation in the Isha programmes, every volunteering opportunity with Isha, the profoundly tramsformative visits to Isha Yoga Center and Sadhguru Sannidhi in Bengaluru, and every personal and professional experience, they are all culminating with this new step for my growth : Sadhanapada. 
It is a bit scary, but I know it is the right step for my growth and I am grateful that I have this chance. 
When I volunteer I do my best to offer myself fully and I know that while I will grow in ways I cannot even imagine, I will also contribute with my involvement, in whatever area I will get the chance to volunteer as part of Sadhanapada. 
Thank you for this opportunity.

column54: I want to dedicate a focused time for deepening and intensifying my sadhana and work towards establishing yogic practices well into my life and Sadhanapada seems like a perfect opportunity. I feel that somehow, something is lacking in the way I am doing my daily sadhana. I have felt very pleasant after doing my sadhana and how well I could handle rest of my day because of that, but it remains a rare happening yet. I want it to become a regular happening in my life or even a frequent one for now. Volunteering has helped me understand my limitations and I have become willing since I have started doing it. I still feel a certain resistance, when it comes to taking up tasks at home or other aspects of my life and through this program I wish to become willing not only while volunteering at Isha, but also in all aspects of my life. I have been working since 3 years now and I am of age to get married, so before getting involved with another person and taking up responsibility, now seems like a perfect time for me to dedicate this time for my spiritual growth and enhance my ability to handle various situations.
column55: It will be challenging at first of course to get adapted to the schedule, but I am willing to participate in it fully. It is a good challenge for me, to get to know my physical and mental limitations through this and trying to overcome them.

column54: First of all, I thought of participating in this program after completing my college but I got placed in a company and then I thought of getting work experience for at least 2 years, but I constantly kept thinking of what do I do next in my life. So, I chose this path to first get a clarity on life and on how I should feel, think, talk, respond, and be with myself, so that when I be with others or in the world outside I am a much more better person.
column55:
1. Daily Schedule - In my life, whenever I was in college hostel or stayed alone, I used to follow a schedule like waking up early, doing my practices and then going to college or work. But whenever I was at home for holidays or any other day, I am not regular in waking up early and following a schedule as I feel more relaxed there. So, I think whenever I am left alone I will give my 100 percent to follow the schedule. 
 
2. Personal Time - One thing about me, I have very few friends to whom I talk rarely. The one person to whom I share everything is my mother but I wanted to know how it would be or how will I decide if I am left alone. So I find this as an opportunity to make me rely on myself for everything that I do and think. 
 
3. No Days Off - I am working in an IT company and I always waited for the weekend but whenever weekend arrives, I simply do household chores, in my free time scroll through reels, eat, sleep and not do anything productive. Instead of spending weekends like this, I feel it would be great if it would go productive. Even though, I tell this I know that it might be difficult for me to accept this but as days go by I think I will be able to adapt to it and will even forget what day it is while being in the ashram.
column56:
1. Walking long distances - In my work, I go to office only twice a week as it is hybrid, that to in two wheeler. So I don't walk that frequently. But when I initially joined the company and was in a hostel. I used to walk a total of 4 kms in a total to go to the office and come to the hostel daily. Also during college days I used to walk 4 times from college to hostel in the morning and for lunch and in the evening. So, even though now I don't walk much, I am used to walking and I think I'll be able to do it subsequently. 
 
2. Sitting cross legged - Whenever I work from home, I sit on the floor and work. But still I'll practice sitting cross legged and in arthasidhasana for more time before I come to this program. 
 
3. Difficult Activities - I am not a person to usually do physical activities and heavy lifting, but if that is the seva I am assigned to I'll go through it and train my body to break that limitation as well.
column57: I am willing to do the activity assigned to me. One thing about me I have not done physically intense jobs before like shifting heavy objects, working in the fields for long time and it would be difficult for me to do it initially. But as days go by I think I'll be able to adapt to that.
column58: During my college days, I shared my room with 3 other roommates, so a total of 4. And also from the webinar I got to know that we come to the stay area only to sleep, so I think it will be fine for me to be in a dormitory stay area with a four sharing room and share bathroom facilities. I've got a experience in volunteering as I've volunteered in my local centre and also at the Ashram, so it would be fine for me to mingle with people and do things during volunteering activities.
column59: Even though my family thought that leaving a job with salary is a difficult decision, they are satisfied that they are sending me to the right place for the betterment of my inner wellbeing. My family suggests that searching and getting a job will not be a difficult process but if I miss this chance of being in the ashram and working on myself, it would be hard for me to make this same decision again in the future.

column36: He Did his IE in Mar 2024 and subsequently did his Guru Pooja and BSP in May and August respectively. When he was at the ashram for advanced programs, he saw the commitment and involvement with which the volunteers supported the program really touched him just sleeping for 4 hours (12am and 4 am). Also his Shambavi experience at the ashram during the programs were explosive. Seems he had a friend who did her hatha yoga teacher training last year. He could not recognize her after the training as her complete personality and everything about had changed. He was really inspired by her. After he found out about Sadhanapada, he felt he had to go for it to deepen his sadhana and fix himself. He feels he is doing very good with Shambavi, but his lifestyle (his job shift is from 4pm to 1 am and he feels lazy and sleepy), distraction due to constant social media scrolling is something hes still struggling with. Also he volunteers every month with the local center and really loves the sangha concept at Isha.

I know I am capable of doing lots of things but I don't have chance to test my limits and showcase my skills. column11: As a package handler, I operate in a fast-paced, changing environment where I work the early morning shifts which have an average start time range from 4:00 AM to 4:30 AM. In other words, every Monday through Saturday, I‚Äôm waking up at 3:00 AM. During the morning shift, my primary responsibilities are lifting, loading, and sorting. Ever since my third day of hire, a constant factor on this job is lifting/carrying packages of different shapes, sizes, and inner contents each weighing varyingly from as light as a sheet of paper to items as heavy as the combined weight of three well-fed, large dogs. Furthermore, in addition to loading (or unloading) these items onto (or from) the tight spaces of various types of delivery vehicles, as a package handler, we are responsible for scanning, sorting, and physically arranging packages by their respective destinations. Each day is different, as we operate according to business demands. Some days of the week, I‚Äôm asked to start my shift as early as 2:00 AM and I would be on the clock until 9:00 AM or sometimes 10:00 AM. Other days except for Saturdays, I work the evening shifts which tend to go from 6:30 PM - 10:00 PM.
