column54: At this point in time, my life situations are aligning with this growing desire to allocate a dedicated length of time for just sadhana and imbibing the energies of the consecrated space of the Isha Yoga Center. Already, I am thirty minutes closer to my grave since I started contemplating and articulating my reason as to why I wish to go through Sadhanapada at this particular time. And in the moments I am aware of this moment-to-moment truth ‚Äîthat I am mortal and one day I will end‚Äî the mind looks at the activities I have done, the activities I want to do, and the activities I am doing and wonders, ‚ÄúAm I using this Energy, that has been allocated to me, sensibly?‚Äù For me, to determine whether this Energy is being used sensibly, one has to first set a direction. My direction is Sadhguru, my direction is Life, my direction is to allow this piece of Life to radiate and begin to experience Life beyond the limitations I am aware of and currently beholden to. In other words, my direction is to clean out and empty all the nonsense/untruth that I have built up so that I can finally be. In this effort, spending dedicated time going through this blessed, seven-month opportunity to weave a pressure-cooked cocoon from the sutras of a Living Master is the way I would like to make use of the Energy given to me.
column55: Back in Spring of 2022, I was a participant in the Men‚Äôs 21 Day Sadhana Program at the Isha Institute of Inner Sciences in Tennessee with about 20-30 other participants. Our schedule during those 21 days, was waking up by 4:30am at the latest, starting guru pooja at 5:30am sharp, chanting the maha mantra, doing group guided sadhana until about 9am, and several other structured activities for that respective day. There were no days off, I adhered to the set schedule absolutely, and happily died into the bed at around 10 or 11pm. The program was intense, in fact, a person who travelled on the same shuttle as me to attend this program, decided to leave the program about 7-11 days in because he was unwilling to flow with the rules of the situation created by the 21-day program. In all honesty, I did not realize how intense the program was until after he left. In other words, after he left my experience of the program changed in a subtle but powerful way. I do not even think I was aware at that time how my experience of the program shifted, but I could feel there was a shift. However, when I look back to those moments after that individual left and how I was after, I can see that my willingness in going through various aspects of the program was the primary factor that produced immeasurable yet significant impacts on my profoundness of experience. So one could say I had a taste of Sadhanapada. However, I say ‚Äútaste‚Äù very generously here because despite some of the surface level similarities, I really do not know what to expect out of Sadhanapada other than the fact that nature of program will be even more intense than what I could imagine, as one could infer from the focused length of the program, let alone the latitudinal and geographical location, the number of people, and many more factors. So long answer short, I‚Äôm looking forward to adhering to the strict schedule for a dedicated, consistent period of time to bring about a sustainably resilient inner foundation for alignment and balance to flower on all levels of this body.
column56: If there‚Äôs one thing that I understand about this body it is this, the body adapts to the situations you place it in. So, while I don‚Äôt necessarily have an immediate simulation for activities like farming, I have been increasing my fitness level outside of work by doing jump rope and walking more. Once I manage to work Angamardhana into my yogic sadhana schedule and establish a mandala with the process, I‚Äôm sure I will be better able to go through a larger variety of physical demands with ease. I have already noticed some of the subtle ways Yoga Namaskar, Surya Kriya, and Yogasanas have been improving my physical culture in terms of flexibility, joint strength, spine health, and coordination. Regarding sitting crossed legged, I will continue eating vegetarian, cut out dairy for a while and sit in ardhasiddhasana as much as possible. Back in 2022, when I had volunteered at the Isha Institute of Inner Sciences in Tennessee after the Men‚Äôs 21 Day Sadhana program, while it was at times challenging, I enjoyed the process of being fully involved in whatever activity I was assigned to. And in the nights, I would sleep like a rock hahaha! I can tell from the myriad of YouTube videos, Sadhanapada participant sharings ‚Äîboth in-person and online‚Äî, and even just from the webinar alone that the physical demands of the Sadhanapada program will be cranked up to a higher pitch of intensity than probably all of my experiences of volunteering for Isha Foundation in the United States combined; regardless, I‚Äôm looking forward to wholly go through this process. My preparation is on.
column57: I read this question as, ‚ÄúHow willing are you to experience Sadhanapada?‚Äù The answer is ‚ÄúYes and yes!‚Äù Or, on a scale of 1-10, I am a TEN. One (1) being ‚ÄúI have seva preferences, and I‚Äôll only be fully involved if I get the seva I like or I expect to get.‚Äù And ten (10) being ‚ÄúWhile I don‚Äôt know why I was selected for this seva for this duration of the program, I do know that this seva provides me the best opportunity to grow in this moment as long as I give myself as totally as I can. In other words, I am willing. Wherever I am placed will be the right place for me at that time.
column58: I‚Äôm used to sharing my living space with others, at home, when I attended both high school and university, when I attended residential Isha programs in the United States and India, and when I volunteered for Isha residential programs in the United States. I feel fine about it, I‚Äôm thankful that the residential spaces are there for us to inhabit and support us for the time we will be there.
column59: Before I started this application, I let my immediate family know of my plans to attend Sadhanapada 2025, where I would be residing in Southern India for a minimum period of eight months starting from June of next year. I can only be thankful to them and their willingness to support my efforts in this direction. In fact, you may have seen that I watched the webinar twice. That second time, I watched it with my mum and cousin sister. Furthermore, my family knows that I am well aware of our current financial situation, and that I am actively settling that aspect so that by time May 2025 comes around, the path forward will be more easily walkable. They also have increasingly become aware that since my first Isha program in 2021, that I have made Isha a priority of my life more and more. Furthermore, they have been supportive in my growth all my life in several ways I have been aware of, in several ways I am becoming aware of, and in innumerable ways that I have yet to be aware of. Without their nurture, I would not be where I am today, let alone being aware of a program or even organization of such magnitude. For my mum, even though she is not necessarily an Isha meditator, she‚Äôs the one who introduced me to Sadhguru back in the winter of 2020. For my dad, even though he is not an Isha meditator at all, he‚Äôs always stated to me these two things since I was maybe 10 or 11 years of age: (1) ‚ÄúAs your father and mother, we are your cheerleaders. We want the best for you, so you must always strive to be your best.‚Äù And (2) ‚ÄúThe ball is in your court. It‚Äôs up to you whether you dribble, pass, juggle, shoot, or launch it. That choice is always in your hands. You are the captain of your ship.‚Äù For my cousin sister, she has always wanted to make sure that I am acting and moving forward sensibly, and she would advise accordingly. So long answer short, my family is supportive of me staying at the Isha Yoga Center for the full duration of the program.

column10: Undergraduate Research Assistant for The Adult Learning Lab (TALL for short)
column11: During the time when I was an undergraduate at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC for short), I became a research assistant in Dr. Elizabeth Stine-Morrow‚Äôs cognitive psychology lab known as The Adult Learning Lab (TALL for short). This psychology research lab is located in the Beckman Institute, which is in the northern area of the UIUC campus. As a research assistant, I collaborated weekly amongst a team of nine to eleven individuals about ongoing lab projects. My other responsibilities included, testing various older participants‚Äô cognitive abilities using a rigorous neuropsychological battery, utilizing an analysis method called the Kintsch text-protocol system to analyze over 70 subjects‚Äô data, which allowed us to submit our abstract proposal for the 2020 Cognitive Aging Conference at the Georgia Institute of Technology, and lastly (but most importantly) I maintained positive relationships with lab participants by resolving issues and attending to their needs both over the phone and in person.

During the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC for short) had largely shifted their activities to be online and had significantly reduced instances of in-person campus activities. So, in an effort to facilitate the transition back to in-person campus activities, Wellness Support Associates (WSA‚Äôs for short) were hired with the intention to bring a necessary level of health safety in campus buildings and by extension, the university as a whole. More specifically, as a WSA, I was staffed at the front entrances of classroom buildings to check an individual‚Äôs building access status. One's building access status was displayed through an app called Safer Illinois (at the time) and it showed us --the WSA's-- whether the individual had been vaccinated and currently COVID negative or positive. During that role, I greeted and provided a warm experience to faculty, students, staff, and all who entered the buildings I was stationed at regardless of their building access status. Furthermore, I was trained to resolve, de-escalate, and guide individuals with restricted building access in a timely manner by following the established guidelines of the University of Illinois Campus Security Training.

column47: After my 21 day Sadhana program finished, I was able to stay as a volunteer for some time. I became a long term volunteer at III, and my activities ranged from program volunteering (BSP), to general ashram maintenance activities, like warehouse activities, being in the kitchen, washing the dishes, preparing food, tying sutras, attending the Isha Life Shoppe, and more.

I became a virtual call support volunteer for the then upcoming Inner Engineering Completion Mega Program with Sadhguru in Atlanta and Los Angeles. I was in a group of 30+ volunteers, with 10 of us being regularly active in maintaining our pre-committed call support schedule. It was a great experience talking with all kinds of people and answering their inquiries regarding the mega program, isha, or sometimes life in general. It was also fulfilling to see one of the mediators I spoke with over the phone at the Atlanta venue!

This was for Inner Engineering Completion with Sadhguru in Atlanta, Georgia. While, the program dates were June 3-4th, hall setup volunteers were asked to arrive two days beforehand. I was primarily a part of the hall setup team, where we were split into groups that were in charge of the various zones that comprised the program hall. Some of my responsibilities were systematically measuring and arranging the chairs in such a way that the participants would always be oriented toward Sadhguru and so that we could maintain this orientation when removing and replacing chairs in under short notices! Additionally, I was tasked by an Ishanga to be one of the two mic runners for all the Q&A segments for a hall of over 3400 seekers. It was a blast!

column46: In the Lap of the Master
column47: I was a part of Parking Team, so we were up before dawn and would guide cars into the larger space space area (p4) outside the gates across the street of the ashram premises.

I was a part of hall team, where I was in the class with the participants. I was in charge of making sure they were awake on time and making sure the hall was setup for class. I was with the participants throughout their entire program, it was both a beautiful and learning experience for me.

I was a part of the kitchen team. More specifically, I was in charge of preparing the Sukku in the mornings, and hot lime drink in the afternoon/evening. I was not limited to those tasks, as I would also help with prepping other meals for the participants; however my primary responsibilities were to prepare the drinks and serve them. The serving experience was an ethereal experience for me, from transporting the hot drinks to the biksha dining hall, to arranging the cups in a certain way, to timing when to pour the drink in each cup so that they wouldn‚Äôt be too hot or too cold for the participants, to just basking in the silence. It was truly a wonderful experience. I also enjoyed being able to offer Guru Pooja a few times in the morning before we started our tasks for the day.

column54:
- Sadhanapada is a must-do in my life, I have failed twice and succeeded last year yet couldn't go because of visa difficulties, each failure was a big blow, however, each time my desire to go has grown much stronger and stronger 
- I have volunteered in Linga Bhairavi Temple in Nepal last year and this year in Isha Institute of Inner-sciences in Tennessee, my body knows the significance of consecrated spaces, and feels their absence after coming back, IYC is a must-go, numerous times I have imaged myself near the presence of Dhyanalinga, I must be there 
- Timewise speaking Sadhanapada is also beautifully designed by Sadhguru, July to Mahashivratri is most beneficial for spiritual growth, besides solar flares are dancing with us these years, it couldn‚Äôt be better 
- I also wish to do Samyama in IYC 
- Sadhanas in the Abode of III felt like a breeze, but a little bit of struggle after coming back, this is the importance of good ambience for spiritual growth, I wish to strengthen my sadhanas during Sadhanapada, and learn more sadhanas if I have the chance 
- I am facing career change, fear and doubt make me hesitate to move forward, by Sadhanapada I wish to transform myself to be more joyful & disciplined & unwavering no matter what I do 
- I‚Äôve learned that Seva & Sadhana is great combination to demolish one‚Äôs ego/karma and to be more available to grace, this is what Sadhanapada is about, it‚Äôs similar to my volunteering experience in Nepal & US but so much more intense & disciplined, and it‚Äôs exactly what I want
column55:
- as Shoonya Intensive & BSP alumni I have totally experienced isha‚Äôs way of conducting programs‚Äî‚Äîfully scheduled, cut out from the outside world and fully dedicated to one‚Äôs inner growth, I understand it, endorse it, and would totally go by it 
- In BSP I was amazed by how beautifully and intelligently the program was designed‚Äî‚Äîit was so conversational, it‚Äôs like Sadhguru knew what I gonna think and feel and had already prepared the next step for me, he was not there but he was totally present, Sadhanapada must be the same, beautifully designed by Sadhguru, I would totally embrace his grace without saying a word 
- again I know why Sadhanapada is designed like this and it‚Äôs totally what I what‚Äî‚ÄîI‚Äôd love Sadhguru pushing me towards higher possibilities
column56:
- I have just come back from 6 month volunteering in III Tennessee, did every possible seva, lots of them involves heaving lifting like gardening, warehouse, housekeeping etc., and I love them, great to stretch the body in nature, food felt so much more delicious 
- interesting fact, first two month in III my Apple Watch constantly congratulated me ‚Äúyou have walked longer distance!‚Äù ‚Äúyou have climbed more stares!‚Äù ‚Äúyour resting heart rate is lower than before!‚Äù , after coming back it‚Äôs constantly lamenting ‚Äúyour walking distance has been lower‚Äù ‚Äúyour total working out time has been declining‚Äù‚Ä¶ hahaha wish to go back volunteering!!! 
- sounds like bragging again, in III other volunteers was amazed why I was always running instead of walking among locations, while, I want to save time and I love running! can‚Äôt wait to run in IYC where the whole land is consecrated 
- about sitting cross legged, after getting addicted to Sadhguru I have given away my expensive ergonomic chair and sit cross legged on the ground ever since, it‚Äôs much more scientific and comfortable way to be
column57:
- totally willing to do whatever assigned, at the Bhairavi Temple in Nepal I did everything except selling and in III did every seva except administration, no matter it‚Äôs physically intense or office based, I would do whatever needed 
- doing whatever needed is both good for myself and the ashram, good for the ashram, while ashram have lots of work to be done especially IYC takes so many social responsibilities, good for myself because by demolishing likes & dislikes, sevas could loosen our karma/ego structure and make us more available to grace
column58:
- like India, China is crowded, we have grown up in dormitory culture 
- in III Tennessee I shared the room with 6 others, very natural for me
column59:
- in the beginning they were not supportive ‚Äúyou are thirty something now and why are you still doing this nonsense!? you should earn more money, get married and have a son to pass down our family name!!!‚Äù 
- when I was in Nepal they were afraid of me becoming a monk‚Ä¶ 
- gradually they see how happier and more vibrant I am after coming back from Nepal and US, now they have changed the attitude ‚Äúdo whatever you and to do for one more year and then get married OK?‚Äù hahaha

column54:
After attending the Inner Engineering program and learning Hatha Yoga and Shoonya, my body, emotions, and perspective on the world have undergone a tremendous transformation. I am no longer easily carried away by thoughts and emotions, and I feel more at peace and joyful. This change has made life feel entirely different, and yet I realize how little I truly know about life. I am eager to experience more at the Isha Yoga Center while I am in good physical and financial health. Therefore, I am very keen to go through the Sadhanapada program to experience more of the unknown and the possibilities it offers. 
I hope that through various events in the program, I can fully dedicate myself and let go of my ego, surrendering entirely to life and allowing life to be life itself.
column55:
Initially, I thought it might be exhausting, and I might feel a desire to resist or escape. However, my perspective changed completely after volunteering for the Shoonya program in Hong Kong this August. During the Shoonya volunteering, I only slept 2-3 hours each day, continuously engaged in various tasks and responsibilities, with no personal time whatsoever. Through this complete immersion, my body adapted from initial fatigue to a state of lightness and ease. I felt an overwhelming sense of joy and operated at an efficiency I had never experienced before, which was both entirely new and profoundly beautiful. By the end of the course, I felt reluctant to leave. 
Therefore, I look forward to experiencing this beauty again through the intensity of the Sadhanapada program.
column56:
As someone who usually spends long hours in an office, any activity away from the office makes me happy. :) 
I grew up in a rural area in China and have experience with farming. In my daily life, I also keep up with regular Hatha practice and long walks, so I feel I can handle the physical demands of the program.

column54:
I believe by going through sadhanapada, I can develop a more stable basis so I will be less influenced by others' wishes can have more clarity and how to achieve what I want. 
I recently attended the BSP program at Isha Institute of Inner Sciences. During my time there, I had such clarity and courage to make decisions that aligned with who I was, that it was incredible. After coming home, my old habits of being influenced by external factors (like other's opinions & wishes, monetary concerns, etc.) started to reappear again. I want to deepen my practices and my sadhana so I can continue to live with a clear and conscious mind, allowing me to make the best decisions towards achieving the goal of helping others become more conscious and willing to live and be involved. 
I believe this is the perfect time for me since I budgeted myself two years of self-exploration after quitting my job. One year has already passed and it has helped me realize I need to learn how to consciously stand up for the life inside me instead of unconsciously living in autopilot or trying to appease others. Thus, I want to take the next step of becoming a "full-fledged" human being and I think this would be the best possible option.

column54:
I wanted to initiate and fulfill my spiritual needs with full involvement and devotion since after completion of 2019 free inner-engineering program offered during Diwali (I have completed inner-engineering again recently in march 2024.) I wanted to initiate my spiritual journey under Guru's presence who will initiate me to become a full time spiritual seeker but I was tangled up in work and family situations, currently I am 31 years old, eldest in three siblings in the family of five. Due to some legal business dispute which took too long to get resolved I was giving my full attention day and night to my work and family and being an introvert i am struggling to get directions from anywhere in regards with spirituality. Though the nearest Isha yoga center from my town which is Chhatarpur, Delhi is not too far it's around two and half hour travel (one way) on my scooter or car (traffic included), i am not able manage to go there or join any programs there even once though I had plans. And now as court matters have been resolved to the level which is manageable and business is running smoothly I will surely be able to visit Chhatarpur (Delhi) center in coming days and seek necessary guidance but being always in presence of guru during Sadhanapada will definitely accelerate things. 
Why this particular time I wanted to join Sadhanapada? It's more like now and never kind of a situation for me, As we are three of us (me, my father and my younger brother) handling our joint business which are segregated in two segments hence needing at least two members all the time to keep things going. As my father is aging (he is 61 currently) he might retire soon in coming years so i want to initiate my spiritual journey before he decides to retire. And after Sadhanapada i will continue my spiritual journey at home in full throttle with continuing supporting my immediate family. I will retire from my business as time will come on the path to become a full time sadhak/monk. (My ultimate goal is to attain moksha, atleast i want to give it my best).

column36: He mentioned his father and brother will be able to take care of the business while he is off as all 3 manage the business together anyways.

He already has experience living in shared spaces when he was preparing for his CA and can easily adjust with simple amenities. He is having only 2 meals a day and eats only sattvic food since his IE. Wakes up around 6-7 am and goes to bed 9-10 pm usually. (If its festival season he's busy in his shop and goes to bed only at 11). He is used to intense physical work (loading and unloading 600 quintals of material) for his business when his employees are not around. He is touched by sadhguru and want to contribute through seva in any way possible.

He is a partner in two family businesses - retail business of kitchen utensils and other is his family business of hookah pot manufacturing. He deals with customers on day to day basis taking bulk orders and is good with people. He was trying to crack CA for 2-2.5 years years after his B Com. But did not end up finishing the finals and decided to run his family business. Hes been part of his family business since 2016.

Languages known

Hindi & English : Read, Write, Speak, Understand
Punjabi : Speak and Understand
He did B.Com in Open University (part of Delhi University) and graduated in 2013.

His dad is 61 and his mom is 56. Both are physically healthy and are independent. He has a sister who is 28 years old who lives with them. she is unmarried and not working. He is yet to have a detailed discussion about SP with his dad. His dad is not into spirituality but looks out for him and wants the best for him. It seems he is not able to understand why one has to leave home for 8 months for sadhana . He mentioned he will talk to his dad and we can call his father in a week or two.
He mentioned he has a enough money available as he manages two business (mentioned he can comfortably get many cars now) and should be easily able to manage any expenses during SP.

He was supporting his father with a legal case regarding his business filed by his father against a bank. He mentioned the case is already settled and signed a month ago and he will never have to step out or manage the case when hes here in SP.

He is regular with his Shambavi since initiation and finished his mandala after as well. There are some minor practice corrections needed for him (Sukha kriya he is not starting and ending it correctly). He agreed to reach out to Ishanga and also attend a sathsang to get it corrected. 

 He mentioned he did not do Shambavi for a month after mandala as he lost 8 kgs and was worried. But he continued to do after as he realized it might be due to his poor eating habits and started switching to a satvic lifestyle. 


Volunteering : He has not done any Isha Volunteering as after in IE in March he has been busy with his business or helping his father with the legal case. He mentioned he will surely come to IYC and volunteer now as he has time now. 

He has other volunteering experiences outside Isha.

1. He has been serving food at his Gurudwara regularly for all Purnimas for many years (he thinks it should atleast be 15 years)

2. He also volunteers with supporting the Smashan Ghat (cremation ground) near his place. There is a lot of wood needed at a very short time and he always helps out with that (carrying it from different locations) as he sees this as seva.

Applicant is very enthusiastic and mentioned multiple times he wants to live under a Gurus guidance. He is touched by Sadhguru after shambavi and since SP is part of Sadhguru Gurukulam he wants to be part of it.

He doesn't have any loans under his name. But his business (his dad, him and his brother together) have some loans , But he mentioned that is just his working capital (and that is not anything new as that's how they operate). He mentioned that will not be any concern as that's a very small amount for the profits they make.

Physical Ailments : He has asthma when he was a child but no concerns after.

1. He mentioned about a scooter accident 3 years ago where he had a tendon or ligament tear (hes not sure which) on his shoulder. He had a sling for a month but continued to work in his shop. Never got hospitalized. He doesn't have any pain or issue reg this now and doesnt take any medication, follow up.

2. He got affected by Covid. He lost taste completely for 15 days. Seems he did not take any Covid vaccinations as he wanted his body to develop immunity. He agreed to follow health, immunization protocols as prescribed during his stay for SP though.

Mental Ailments : No Concerns

Intoxicants : He mentioned he stared consuming alcohol 2 years ago. But it was just again whenever he met with his friends (missed to ask the frequency). However stopped it after IE. He mentioned his reason for stopping alcohol was that he was not having good sleep, feeling drowsy and ended up missing sadhana once. He did not want that as he really liked his shambavi. So he never took alcohol after.

Practices : He is regular with his Shambavi since initiation and finished his mandala after as well. There are some minor practice corrections needed for him (Sukha kriya he is not starting and ending it correctly). He agreed to reach out to Ishanga and also attend a satsang to get it corrected. 

He mentioned he did not do Shambavi for a month after mandala as he lost 8 kgs that got him worried. But he continued to do after as he realized it might be due to his poor eating habits and started switching to a satvic lifestyle since then.

Lifestyle : He is pretty active throughout the day at his shop. He is used to intense physical work (loading and unloading 600 quintals of material) for his business with his employees are not around. Already has only 2 meals a day. Wakes up around 6-7 am and goes to bed 9-10 pm usually. (If its festival season hes busy in his shop and goes to bed only at 11)

column36: Anna quit his job as an accountant a year ago and came to India back from Dubai and started working on his ancestral farm after his father passed away. Earlier he had more responsibilities on the farm with few/no labours. Currently, his family built a building for the labours to stay and got enough labours to manage the farm so that he can spend dedicated seven months in the ashram. His mom is going to manage all the labours for farming.

Anna visited IYC 15 to 16 times till now at Coimbatore, attended Devi seva for 21 days, and knows many aspects of the ashram like food, clothing, seva and stay area. He has stayed in Adiyogi Alayam during Devi seva, lived in hostel for 5 years before, so he is comfortable with shared stay during the program.

Anna worked as an accountant for five years in Dubai from 2017 to 2023. He had to close the debt from his father's cancer treatment. He returned back to India after closing the debt and started working on his ancestral farm to continue his legacy since his mom alone was not able to manage it and also to be with nature.

He has a hobby of playing badminton for three hours everyday for physical activity.

Anna finished this B.Com degree in 2013, studied chartered accountant from 2013 to 2020. He is planning to give the CA final exam after sadhanapada, not for a career but just to finish the degree in the last step. He wants to parallelly manage his farm too while studying for CA.

Anna is fluent in Kannada, Tulu, English, Hindi. He can also understand Tamil and Telugu.

Father passed away in 2013 with NHL cancer. Younger sister is working on CA finals and also working as a lecturer. Mother used to manage the farm by herself before but she had a surgery to get the Uterus removed and now cannot do physical work but she guides anna and labours to work on the farm.

Applicant sister has already attended Sadhanapada and been an inspiration for him to take on this program. His mother has no problem of him attending the program and there is no dependency on him either in any way. Consent call can be done to mother to confirm.

Anna had a huge debt of his father's cancer treatment when he passed away so he had to go to Dubai to earn money and closed the debt in 2022 completely.

Anna said he has more than enough amount of money for him to sustain the whole seven months earned on farming. His house hold members are not dependent on him especially when they have enough labours for the farm.
None

Anna has finished Isha programs: Shambhavi Mahamudra, Yogasanas, Surya Kriya, BSP, Bhairavi program, guru puja, Angamardana, Shivanga Sadhana. He is waiting to do Samyama in 2026 by preparing himself through Sadhanapada 2025. 

On daily basis he is doing Shambhavi mahamudra, Shoonya, SCK, Yogasanas and guru pooja. He also has a non-Isha practice called Rama Tanki which is a ritual he performs at home. His family can replace him for the practice when he is in Sadhanapada. 

Anna remembers all the Shambhavi steps correctly and it takes him 40 mins to finish preparatory asanas ad shambhavi.

He volunteered at IYC Coimbatore for Devi seva. He also has been volunteering locally in his village temple since childhood like decoration during festivals, serving to devotees etc.

Anna was very enthusiastic during the call and transparent about everything. He was smiling constantly and very content about the farming legacy he has been carrying forward.

Anna said he is content without marriage at this point in life, so he is not thinking about it.

Anna will have to step out of the ashram for 3 days in August next year to perform his father's death ceremony at home.
His family takes a Crop loan of 3 lakhs with 0 percent interest because he can claim it as farmer's benefit but don't really need the loan. They repay the loan every end of year.

Since 1 year, his schedule is: 7.30am wake up, Sadhana till 10.30am, breakfast at 1040am, starts working on farm from 11am to 2pm, 3pm lunch, 4pm-5.30pm farm, tea/coffee snack, 7pm-10pm badminton, sleep at 10.30pm. Sometimes, he has heavy dinner and sleep after 12am.

Since 10 days he changed his schedule. 4.30am wake up, guru pooja, 3 Bhairavi stutis till 8am, play for 2 hours, 8to10am practices, 10.15am breakfast, CA final study and the rest of the schedule is same.

Anna drinks tea twice every day.

column54: At this point in my life, I feel there is a part of me that remains unfulfilled. While I may be working hard, I sense that I am not operating at my full potential, or perhaps I am, but I am still not satisfied with where I am. I wish to fully own and enhance this potential, focusing my attention and energy to reach my true capabilities. I believe the Sadhanapada program will provide me with the tools and environment needed to explore this part of myself, helping me grow into a more focused and empowered version of myself.
column55: I believe that following a strict daily schedule, having limited personal time, and adhering to the program‚Äôs expectations and ashram guidelines are essential for my inner growth. I have always wanted to adopt a structured routine, waking up early and engaging in purposeful activities. Although this schedule is more demanding than my current one, it aligns with the direction I want to take in my life. I understand it won‚Äôt be easy, but I am ready to embrace it with an open mind and a willingness to grow. I see this as an opportunity to strengthen my discipline and focus, knowing it will lead to something meaningful.
column56: I believe the physical demands of the program, such as walking long distances, sitting cross-legged, and engaging in challenging activities like farming, are ultimately for our own physical well-being. I actually enjoy physical work, and sitting cross-legged feels natural to me, as it‚Äôs something I‚Äôve done since childhood. While farming may be new to me, I am excited about the opportunity to learn. I‚Äôve always had a small hobby of gardening at home, which has helped me feel connected to nature, so I don‚Äôt foresee this being an issue. In fact, I think it will be a rewarding experience.
column57: The webinar has made it clear that it's not about seeking comfort but about fostering inner growth. With that in mind, I am fully willing to be assigned to any kind of volunteering activity, whether it is physically demanding or office-based, for the entire duration of the program. I understand that each task has its purpose, and I don‚Äôt want to be selective or seek comfort in what I do. My focus is on fully immersing myself in seva and embracing the experience, knowing that this is key to my personal growth.
column58: Sharing space with many other volunteers, such as in a dormitory or shared bathroom facilities, is a bit outside my comfort zone, as I‚Äôm used to having more personal space. However, I see this as an opportunity for growth. It‚Äôs something I‚Äôd like to work on, as learning to live and collaborate with others in close quarters will be valuable for me, not only during the program but also in life. I believe this experience will help me become more adaptable and open, which is a crucial part of the journey.
column59: My family is supportive of my decision to stay at the Isha Yoga Center for the full seven-month duration of the program. While they may not fully understand all the aspects of the program, they trust my decisions and believe that it is for my own good. They have always supported my personal growth and are not going to stand in the way of this important journey in my life. Their trust and support give me confidence in committing to this experience wholeheartedly.

column54: I've applied to Sadhanapada for the past two years. The first year I applied, I went through the entire process and my aim was to delve deep into the core of my sadhana, as I had just been initiated that year into Shambhavi. I realized through the application process however that I was not yet ready. I was not accepted into the program that year. The next year (last year) I applied again, but decided my finances and certain aspects of my life were either not in order, or not yet clear enough for me to proceed, so I dropped out of the application process. I have spent the last two years readying my finances, delving deeper into my sadhana, volunteering, and applying with great precision what I've learned through Isha, and it has transformed my life completely in so many different ways. I am now feeling certain that this is the time. I am ready and willing to participate in Sadhanapada, and to deepen my sadhana even more profoundly.

Since I knew Sadhguru via online media, I always wanted to do more of the practices he shared. From the day I retired from my teaching job, I embarked on programs that came my way, i.e. Yogasana, Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya, Kailash Manasarovar Sacred walk, Hatha Yoga Intensive and volunteering at local centre. Currently I am confirmed for Bhava Spandana 16 Dec 2024 session followed by long-term volunteering at Ashram. 
As I am no longer youthful, I think it is time to spend more time on Sadhana. Thus Sadhanapada is the ideal space for me to further my practices namely, Shoonya and Samyama. My husband also kept reminding me to do it since I have the time and am still have the physical and financial capability. Personally when I completed the 21-days Hatha Yoga Intensive program, I remarked to my class that it is the best gift for oneself to gain balance and inner growth. Now that I really understand Sadhanapada, this is another wonderful gift to myself for my spiritual growth.

column54:
I am looking forward to being able to live at the Ashram Space, with people who are seeking the same purpose of growing and breaking limitations. In this context, after watching the video, and the people who were doing Sadhanapadana when I was at the ashram last month, I am excited to grow in many ways: physically, improving my flexibility, stamina, regeneration, endurance and strength; mentally, becoming sharper, and clearer in my mind, with more equanimity; Emotionally, having more intensity, fluidity and conscious of them; and Energetically, improving my energy levels, and consciously start knowing them more closely. 
Also, developing more awareness, perception of life, and being able to connect more profoundly with the oneness that intellectually I can understand the universe is. 
I am striving to break my limitations, I see clearly that I don't want to live with them anymore, and it is okay if they are here for some more time now, but not much time, want to be free of them as soon as possible.

column54:
From last 6 years I have been seeking, and this year (2024) only I found the teachings of Sadhguru. Then I was initiated into Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya and then I went through Bhava Spandana and then I got initiated into Shoonya. 
I have now realized that I have to work on making myself receptive to Grace which is ever present rather than what I was doing before which was trying to reach somewhere. I have also realized that I need to work towards my willingness and for that I wish to go through Sadhanapada at this particular time. 
There are many ways in which I am hoping to grow through the program which includes living in a consecrated space, building willingness through volunteering into Seva, living among other Sadhaka, regularity in the practice of Kriya.
column55: Since the program is designed by Sadhguru himself, I can see that the design looks challenging and at the same time necessary to bring the willingness in the participant that is required for their transformation. To transform myself the way the program expects, it makes sense to fully commit to the guidelines and requirements given. I see all these as necessary to create enough willingness to be "ON" all the time.
column56: I feel the activities can be physically demanding but at the same time essential to learn what it takes to be involved into something. Since there is no physical ailment in me right now, I am sure I will be able to commit 100% to any physical activity in spite of how demanding it might be.
column57: I am willing and excited to be assigned any kind of volunteering activity during the full duration of the program. I am sure I'll be able to perform any office-based activity and even the physically intense activities given I'll be in good health at that time.
column58: I am comfortable with sharing my space with many other volunteers.
column59: Six years ago, I left an IT corporate job and started backpacking and then I gradually watched myself transformed into a Seeker. Initially it was difficult for my parents to understand why I am doing what I was doing, but gradually they have come to terms that they have told me to do whatever I feel is best for my life. The relationship between me and my parents is in much better health now and I am sure they don't mind me staying at the Isha Yoga Center for the full duration of the program as long as I know that this is the best thing to do for my life.

column54: Sadhanapada has been on my mind since the day I heard about it. I only could come to it now. I have been planning for it the past two years. I had intended to complete the film school in Prague and then apply for Sadhanapada. Now - why am I going into this. I have dedicated a lot of time to a lot of things. I studied in many places in the world and travelled a lot - I did so many things. I gave everything time. I also gave Sadhana its time - the past 8 years I have been doing my Sadhana. But I didn't give Sadhana focus full - 100% time. I find that it is unfair that the most important aspect of my life hasn't received a fully focused attention. This is why I wish to plunge into Sadhanapada and allow myself to neither be distracted nor strive for anything else. I just want to give the "inner" absolute attention and focus. I am ceratain that there will be no better place or time to do that than at the Ashram and to do it as soon as possible. I have been to the Ashram 4 times. I already know that when I am in that space I am able to leave the world and all my plans aside. This is an opportunity to do dive long enough and deep enough to see what will come out of it.

column36: To intensify his practices and go through this transformative process, to be more exubrant, joyful, stable and commit himself for this 7 month of growth.
column54: For as long as I can remember, I have always been looking for an authentic process for personal exploration and transformation, and when I came across Sadhanapada back in 2022, I immediately knew that this is it. By participating in the program, I want to commit myself and stay at the ashram for at least 7 continuous months to fully immerse myself into the yogic practices Sadhguru offered and see the profound impacts theses practices bring. In the end, I hope to explore deeper on the nature this life. In addition, I aspire to become a better version of myself after these 7 months, where hopefully I will be a more balanced, stable and joyful human being with more compassion and clarity in life. I just have a deep longing for self exploration and transformation and I just know that there is nothing in the world right now that is potent and powerful as Sadhanapada. And for the past 2 years, Sadhanapada has always been in the back of my mind.
column55: I revered the way Sadhguru designed the strict daily schedule at the ashram and I know it is done with the best intentions. column54:
I have recently been initiated into Shambhavi Mahamudra, and the practice has had a profound impact on both my mental and physical well-being. This transformative experience has made me realize that now is the perfect moment to immerse myself deeper into the yogic path through the Sadhanapada program. 
 
Additionally, I am currently at a phase in my life where there are no external pressures, such as marriage, allowing me the freedom to focus entirely on my inner growth. As I approach 30, I want to participate in this program while I am in good health, so I can fully embrace the physical, mental, and spiritual demands it entails. After Sadhanapada, I also plan to pursue higher education, potentially a PhD, and I believe this experience will provide a strong foundation for that journey. 
 
Above all, attending Sadhanapada in the presence of Sadhguru is a deeply personal aspiration. His guidance has been pivotal in my life, and I feel a deep calling to be in his presence during this transformative phase.

column54: I have been wanting to do Sadhanapada for the last 3 years and was supposed to join the 2022 batch. But there were personal commitments I had to settle and hence I had made a decision to take up an assignment that had come to me at the same time and complete it. I have finished settling my personal requirements and also completing the task I had undertaken by April 2025. Hence, I feel from within that it is time for me to experience Sadhanapada. I hope to focus and discover new things about myself during the program. I have been through intense experiences with Sadhguru in the advanced programs that I have attended. I have heard what he has said about Sadhanapada. I therefore want to do the program now as Iam in the best of my health and spirit. I wish to become a better person and something within me says that I may be able to expand my vision of the world around me, enhance my capability, discover new areas of my strengths, and evolve much more than I can ever imagine . I trust this journey which I want to experience in my life will help me to discover my true self and nature. Hence, I want to invest this time when my Guru is around. I have worked more than 20 years in varied sectors like defence, Airports, corporates but there is something more I am searching for, trying to find my true self. I wish to be in the consecrated space of Isha and go through this program which I know is intense. I wish to discover myself in the process.It will also give me an opportunity to contribute towards the SaveSoil movement. Although I have been in Aviation for more than 20 years, I had done my graduation and a year of masters in Agricultural marketing and cooperation. I love nature, working with farmers and connecting to the amazing projects of Isha. I hope to contribute to Sadhguru's vision. I think this course will help me spread my horizon to real issues, give me an opportunity to touch lives and discover things that I could never imagine I would do.

‚úî She is 38 and lives in China.

‚úî IE has given her a new life (her life goal was to be successful like her father, even after getting everything and having enough money, she did not feel happy). Now even if she faces some struggles she is able to better manage them.

column54:
Since I attended Isha's program for the first time in June 2022, Sadhana has become a very important part of my life, from the practice on the yoga mat, to participating in volunteer‚Äòs work, Sadhana has be integrated into every part of my life. Sadhana has completely changed me. I have 15 years of work experience. I have achieved a lot of success in my work, but the inner pain, struggle and confusion are inevitable until I practice yoga. At first time I did my SadhanaÔºåduring the mandala, I felt relaxed from my heart. After practicing every morning, I became very clear. After working in a complex business and personnel environment for a whole day and returning home, it was like my body was covered with dirt. I felt much cleaner after practicing. The continuous practice made me feel very happy. For the first time, I felt joy (not only joy). After participating in the Inner Engineering volunteer work for the first time, I seemed to have gained a great change. I can be more involved and relaxed in dealing with scenes in work and life without friction. Many things are progressing very quickly. 
In July 2023, I decided to resign my job, I hoped to devote myself to Isha's programs, Sadhana and volunteer works; During this year, I participated in all the activities, programs and Asia-Pacific volunteer works which I could participate in/. Every time I felt some changes, I would feel that Sadhana is so prowerful, but at the same time I could feel that I was still in a very early stage. When we joinning in the sacred walk program, Guru encouraged us not to be entangled, come to the center, and participate in Sadhanapada. After thatÔºåI am eager to participate in Sadhanapada and learn how to do Sadhana well, and I am eager to undergo such a challenge. I hope to be able to build a more stable foundation in the Sadhanapada program thoroughly and comprehensively dismantle the accumulation of "I", be able to accept Sadhanapada‚Äôs training, and maintain my Sadhana under any circumstances, not only for a happy life and work, but for the blossoming and thorough enlightenment of this life; I hope to learn and prepare myself through Sadhanapada and then offer this life to Sadhguru and devote myself to various volunteer work of Isha. I have already made the financial arrangements needed for my family. My family and I are ready for this for me and my husband (my husband has also applied for Sadhanapada and hopes to engage in full-time work in Isha in the future), so I hope to apply for Sadhanapada now.
column55: I have a clear understanding of the strict schedule during the Sadhanapada program and the lack of private time and the need to follow arrangements. I am eager to experience such a strong Sadhana. I know that this is a very sophisticated program designed by Sadhguru, and I am eager to experience this great program. Every time I participate in Isha's volunteer works and programs, I can always feel that there are many subtle coincidences in what work I am assigned to, what situations I encounter, and what partners I work with, which help me recognize or break through some unconscious limitations. I can feel that it is full of grace. No matter what the work is, no matter what the center arranges, I believe it is part of the course. I fully accept it and will work hard to do my Sadhana well, and strive to evolve quickly in this precious opportunity.
column56: Guru has mentioned in many videos about how to sit, and how to stay healthy. I know that every program of Isha is carefully designed, even to a degree that we can't imagine. I know that these arrangements are for us to fully experience this course and realize what this course hopes to achieve. This is also what I have put aside all worldly desires to experience. I fully accept all physical and various arrangements, and I will face and complete all arrangements with tenacity.
column57: I have no expectations or requirements for the arrangement of volunteer work. No matter what work is assigned to me, I will definitely to do my best. I know that this is beyond the logic and calculation of the mind. In the past year or so, I have participated in many volunteer‚Äòs work in the Asia-Pacific region. From the first time I deeply felt that volunteer work is a very remarkable "course", I gradually felt that there are many experiences beyond logic. I was once assigned to clean the toilet in the BSP course. Due to the lack of water in the previous Gent's program, the toilet could not be flushed, so this work became very difficult, but in the process of facing this work, I realized a lot of limitations and broke through a lot. I felt sweet, warm and determined. I am often assigned to work that I may not be good at subjectively, but every time I put in work, I find that I have gained a lot, so I have no expectations for these. I am sincerely grateful to the people who made arrangements for volunteer work behind. And thank them for creating opportunities for us to face and break through ourselves.
column58: I am eager to let go of the limitations of "I" when I join SP. I have no requirements for such external limitations. We have experienced different environments and situations in past courses and volunteer work. In fact, after a day's work, it is enough to have a place to sleep and a simple shower. Occasionally, when volunteer work requires it, we can spread a yoga mat on the floor to sleep without any obstacles. From a material perspective, I have no demand for these, just follow the arrangements of the center.
column59: After practicing yoga for the past two years, my family has seen the changes with my husband and me, and they also hope that we can become healthier and happier. When I quit a good job in 2023 and hoped to devote all my time to yoga, they were supportive and accepted it. My family members are all capable of living independently, and my husband and I have the same wish, and our family also wishes us well in getting the offer from Sadhanapada program.

column54:
To answer this question, I have to begin with my volunteering experience. 
 
I can always go back to the memory of my first volunteering experience for the IE program in Hong Kong. I was not willing, in fact, I was being reluctant and grudging for having the idea of doing volunteer work, but my wife insisted, so I went along. On the first evening, I was lying on the bed in the hotel room and complaining to my wife saying :"Why the hell am I here cutting vegetables and doing all nonsense while I have a lot of work to do for my own project?". I had many conflicts with the coordinator during the day, questioning and challenging her about the detailed procedures and the written code of conduct. When she told me to re-dice the vegetables according to her standard, I almost smashed the knife on the table, I can never forget what I told her on sight:" You come to cut it to your satisfaction if you are not satisfied with mine, I've had enough." 
 
I had no idea of what "volunteer" meant, and I didn't realize how far I was from being a volunteer in life, almost everything I did in life was done with great resistance and fantasy, and now that I look back, with hallucinations. 
 
I didn't say anything at the final meeting, where people shared their experiences. I couldn't wait for the program to finish. I didn't feel much, and I didn't gain much. I thought two days were wasted just like that. 
 
Halfway home on the train, tears started to come, and a few minutes later I started to cry heavily and bitterly. The program touched something deep within, and that was the first time for me to realize that the volunteering part is one of the most important parts of the IE program, that moment I realized how ignorant I was for being arrogant and judging everything I saw in life. As it turned out, it was not "two days wasted" as I imagined at the beginning, it was that I almost wasted such a precious opportunity for being able to volunteer for the program. 
 
It was June 2023, my first grumpy yet life-changing experience. Then the next one came in July, and then August, then it went on just like that. 
 
Up to this point, I have volunteered for four IE programs, Guru Pooja, Shoonya, BSP for Gents and for Ladies. 
 
The volunteer programs opened me up, so much so to the point that I came to realize nothing in material life can satisfy me, nothing can compare to the peace and joy inside this body, and the feeling of making programs complete and see that people being transformed was THE most touching experience I've ever had in life. Programs like these made me understand that life is not just about this being getting something for him/herself, it's about devoting this life to make something happen. 
 
My wife and I went to Kailash Yatra for the second time, and this particular yatra was another major life-changing journey so far. 
 
As we go deeper into the spiritual path, we decided to do everything as if we were volunteering for programs, and we decided to be fully involved in a real-estate project in Sichuan, partnering with our friends and other business partners. We were very decisive about this, and that was just around 10 days before we went for the 2024 Sacred Walk. 
 
On the day we arrived in Lhasa, we shared our stories and plans with Ishanga JiaRui and his wife. "Why are you taking such a detour" Said JiaRui. What they said shocked me. Why would he say that what we were about to do was a detour, it was a sincere choice of walking the spiritual path. On the same night, Ishanga Tanvi said the exact same thing. It took me one day to digest, and then I eventually realized that they were right. Why don't I just go directly onto the spiritual path instead of running around playing the social game. 
 
I was connected with Mahadev during this Kailash Yatra. 
 
Without knowing when the borderline conflict will be resolved between China and India so that we can apply for India Visa, and without knowing what's going to happen in our lives, we decided to give 100% percent to the ultimate truth, and never take any socially conjured detours again. We shut down the company, sold the apartment, wrapping up everything so that we could be 100% with this spiritual path. Then people told us that we should apply for this upcoming Sadhanapada. The idea of applying for this program slipped away in year 2023, now we think it's finally the time that we do this. 
 
We want to become mentally stable with constant clarity, and physically endurable so that we can do heavy-duty work. I remember that Sadhguru said "One can always look back to the Sadhanapada program" because he/she has built this solid foundation, and I want to have this foundation so that I can be ready for whatever might come next. I'm willing to do whatever Sadhguru or Isha tells me to do. I want Sadhguru's wisdom and his teaching to fully imbibe with this being, and I want to become someone like a Bhramachariya, like a stone or a brick, to become someone who's able to handle all kinds of situations and do whatever spirituality tells this being to do. 
 
I am willing, and I am ready.
column55:
I firmly believe that it would train and grind me into such a being which grows toward it's full-fledged form, as I mentioned in the first question, volunteering experience changed me fundamentally, from an arrogant being to become a loving being, from being rigid to being flexible with clarity. 
I believe that the strict daily schedule and everything I will experience during the Sadhanapada will help resolve whatever the nonsense I have left within me.

column36: Spoke to partner about his time off, he's already training 2-3 employees to take care during his absence. He need not attend to his work during his SP. He mentioned they are also going to expand the gym and renovate which is will take 6-months and it'll be closed during this time in 2026.

Has volunteering experience at IYC, so he's aware to some extent and willing to mold himself from now on as a preparation for SP. Meal includes non-veg 3 times in a week, and no problem to incorporate changes till the program time and eat Veg meals at Isha. He likes peanuts in Isha. Fine to sleep in the corridors since he has been travelling to trekking places pilgrimage, he's used to it. He wants fully dedicate his time and not interested in relationships now. He's looking for challenges in the program, both physical and mentally, he wants to grow in all the aspects and he's willing to do whatever is required to be done. After webinar he got to know that there will be no weekends/off, and after 9;30 is silence and sleep, he is being positive about it by seeing that he has been working on Sundays as well from past few weeks and it's fine and preparing himself for it. He's more that happy to sleep at 9;30, since he's not able to sleep early now with his work.

He went to gym to build his muscles, the owner of the gym trained him and gave partnership with no investment from his side, but he gets 50% share in profit. He's working from past 8-9years. He manages the gym, fitness coach, talking to people, take online sessions for UK, US clients. Conducts workshops for how to run Gym business. He used work as Bouncer for events required as part time, but he's not going anymore because he felt it was not for him. Before being a gym trainer, he was also working at Petrol Bunk, Baby Store as Area Manager as part times/full times, he was into many such part times during that period. He mentioned he tried as Body Builder too for an year, he kept changing his work since he was not finding it challenging or interest in it. He feels something is lacking so he's into sadhana now finding stability.

After 10th class, he is involved in sports , he got NA sports and other certification as a course/training, he mentioned as (Open university) in FPF because he didn't find the sports option. He moved to sports side as he felt he was more inclined towards it.

Only mother stays with him, sister is married last year. He wanted to come to SP earlier, but he took responsibility of his sister's marriage and it's done now. Father is expired in 2020 before covid. Mother encouraged him to do IE when he was going through a break-up phase, She's not a mediator but devoted to Linga Bhairavi Devi. Both mother and sister though they had concerns are now convinced , Mother - wanted him to get married, she was worried since he started doing lot of practices lately, but as she saw changes in him, she's happy for him to do SP. He will get married after doing SP, he left the choice of selecting a suitable mate to his mother. Sister was worried after the recent news which has come about 2 girls in Isha. He spoke to her 2hours and she's settled. Father was a alcoholic and expired in 2020, that's the reason he never did any intoxicants.
Saved money for both Mother and himself for the program. He's moving his mother near his sister's house by renting a small house.
None

He was going through a break-up before Shambhavi, he was shouting and angry at that time. his mom suggested him to do IE, after Shambhavi he has become calm, his thoughts became clearer, family member could also notice the changes in him. He was holding a flower very gently in him palm, he was not this aware before IS. And after BSP , that experience stayed with him, till now. He did Shambhavi mandala 3 times, 1sttime - after 1year of initiation, 2ndtime - 2023, 3rd time - now. Otherwise he does 3times in a week given his work schedule. he noticed when there is small break in Shambhavi, he was getting confused and not feeling calm as he talks to many people in a day. that's when he started doing mandala with the App support, he does not use app support during other times. He registered for Shoonya on Nov 28th. and learned Yogasanas last month as preparation for coming Samyama Jan2025. He mentioned he also learnt Surya Shakti 3 times for free at Isha Local Centres.
He felt very happy volunteering at Isha, he came for 7days in Dhyanalinga, Information Centre, Pharmacy, which made him apply for Sadhanapada. during his visit, he sat in Dhayanalinga for 1.5hours, but it felt like 15mins for him and he couldn't hear the bell as well. He did 3 IE program volunteering in different local centres near his place, he did cleaning there. He's happy doing anything which comes his way. He's also part of Isha Youth programs going on now.

Came very presentable on the call, sat in Ardhasiddha asana very stable without moving, with a happy full similing face through out the call. He was very enthusiastic talking about his Sadhana, Isha and Volunteering. During disclaimers, he paid rapt attention and didn't interrupt. Took care of the background, joined the call even before I joined ready with the camera and everything. Was excited to show Devi Pooja place at his work place (Gym) in between the call. But felt like he didn't wanted to share much about his father and his financial situation growing up. Mentioned he has got properties and he was lucky that way. He mentioned he had 3 girl friends over the period of time, after the last break-up he consciously didn't get into any relationship and now his focus is clear. 
Involved in lots of sports - Badminton (district level), Marathons, cricket, Volleyball etc,. Good at managing and talking to people as he will be communicating to his clients daily and also takes business fitness classes. There is Insta account on his name dedicataed for the gym promotion (2.7k followers), Looks very fit , not overweight.
Consent - From Mother, he's okay. Language - Tamil, can call within a week.
EMI, will be done in 6months.

Wakes up at 4am, take online gym class, [Guru Pooja, Yogasanas, Surya Shakti, Yoga Namaskar (21 cycles), Simha Kriya, Isha Kriya, Shambhavi (3 times a week)] divided between morning and evening. he's trying to do all of these practices daily. 3-4pm Nap, 5-5:30 Devi Sadhana, rest of the day work including 6-10pm. sleep at 11pm. Only 1 meal at 1pm, not feeling much hungry after doing sadhana. Meal includes non-veg 3 times in a week (fish, chicken and sometimes Beef)

She got initiated in SMMK in September 2024. She said she completed Mandala & she has been regular with the kriya. When I asked her the steps of the kriya, she was not able to recall it at all intially, then she was guessing each step & all she was mentioning in jumbled sequence. I asked her this is how she does the kriya - she said yes. She then said that she is able to do it 2 to 3 times a week due to work schedule. When I mentioned steps to her, she argued saying she said these asanas. I had to point out regarding sequence & that she is not even sure of the asanas. I asked her to get review session done from local centre. 

When I asked her about tea/coffee, she thought about it & then said no so I am not sure if she said the truth.

Open to share , felt like she was not holding back on any information asked. Her volunteering experience was Incredible.She fell 2-3 times during her volunteering time, she was clumsy at that time. She had one question - if she gets a chance to do Linga Seva or Devi Seva during SP, suggested that she do prior if she really wishes to do it. Enthusiastic to be part of SP, she made all arrangements beforehand so that nothing should interrupt her program. Her mother suffered from Arthritis (knee & elbow) from more than 10 years and then in 2020, she accidentally fell down and had fractures and disc dislocation, she was bedridden for 7-8 months, then recovered slowly and she‚Äôs completely alright now, she only takes physiotherapy once in a week. Even then she took her to complete a health check-up and everything was alright, for her to be in the program. She seems very dedicated and wishes that nothing should interrupt her SP. No marriage plans as such, mother is very supportive in this aspect.
She has friends from SP Alumni , she‚Äôs a Poornanga now in IT (Bhavani), but she didn‚Äôt reveal anything about the program except for tight schedule details.

column54: I feel if we don't get to do Sadhanapada at this particular time, we will not get another opportunity. Here is why: I have been married since last 4 years. Me and my husband both are very afraid and hesitant in becoming parents because in this 4 years, we found ourselves entangled in extreme family and social situations and could not handle it very well. I did not know about Isha Yoga or Sadhguru before my marriage. After our marriage, i heard a lot about it from my husband. As soon as he knew about Sadhanapada, he expressed his wish to do the program. At first, i was not fully convinced just because of the length of the program but very soon i realised that we need to take a break and work on ourselves. After that, we both did IE. It has changed our lives significantly and before we become parents, we must make that foundation more stronger.

column54: Since my 1 month ashram stay as a generel volunteer and doing Linga Seva, i have a deep longing to be there again. This 1 month was the most intense period of my life and i broke many limitations about Food, Sleep, Masturbation and "menial" work. Being back in germany in my comfort zone this breaking limitations has largly stopped and some compulsions like masturbation came back strong again. Since the day of my leave i knew i will come again to the ashram for a longer time. Now my bachelor degree is soon finishing. Originally i wanted to continue doing a masters degree but i want to commit myself fulltime to my spiritual process for a long amount of time. It is the most profound thing in my experience. Additionally, i dont know what i want to do with my life after my studies. Where do i want to live, work and about what shall my work be? When i see so many people being more or less miserable (in their jobs), i feel resistance to enter the same system. I need clarity within myself. Thats why sadhanapada.

He does SMK 20-30 days at a stretch and then another 20-30 days there is a break. He misses SMK due to ad-hoc meetings, sleeping late etc. SMK helps him control his thought process, and stay away from compulsions. When he does SMK whatever is happening around him the day goes smoothly. He is also more calm and empathetic with people working for him. He regrets missing SMK. He does Shoonya and SCK more than SMK but misses that too. He used to do Shoonya regularly until someone told him that SCK is petrol to Shoonya. Since then, if he is not able to do SCK, he has been letting Shoonya go too. He expressed regret in not being regular with Shoonya and SCK.
Anna tried doing mandala for SMK twice but both times it broke. He is going to start SMK mandala from today itself. The last time he did SMK, Shoonya and SCK was last week.

Surya Kriya helps him in a subtle way. It makes him feel light and flexible.

Anna has been here for margazhi sadhana and has also done a pradakshina. He did 3 pradakshina at once when he did for the 1st time and felt a lot of energy.

He went to his hometown just to volunteer for Inner Engineering. Because of travel he didn't get sleep and was on for 2 days. It happened very easily and even though he went there to give, he felt that he got much more.
Anna has a positivity, a light, an optimism about him. There was a shine in his eyes. He is committed to SP and has already started managing his business to be able to come for SP.

No prior Isha Volunteering experience.

Seemed very Committed & Excited for the program. He looked very settled . Didn't notice any strange /weird behavior. 10yrs back his mom asked him to watch Sadhguru video. Those days Sadhgurus video used to come up on Astha Channel & that is how he started following him. He & his mother both used to do Ramdev baba's Yoga by looking at the television. His mother passed away in 2015 due to Brain Hemorrhage. She was actually diagnosed with Malaria first & due to overdose of medicine it led to Brain Hemorrhage. It was a difficult time for him but Yoga somehow helped him to come out of this. He also completed PG Diploma in Yoga & meditation . Has a certificate but doesnt practice it. In the past he has taught it to few people. He also mention when he was in school he had joined this "Bharatiya Yoga Sanstha" & practiced their yoga for 6 months then. IE completed in Jan 2024 through online mode. He feels IE is like a daily capsule for him. It has made him calmer & feels physically fit. Able to handle situations in a better way as he has targets too in his bank. Thereafter he learnt Surya kriya & Angamardana in Ahmadabad early this year from Isha Hatha Yoga teacher(Taradeep). These 2 practices have made his body flexible & also he feels physical fit. In the past he used to sleep for 7-8 hours & now he sleeps only for 5-6 hrs but his energy levels are really high throughout the day. column54: I completed Inner Engineering Online on 7th July,24. Sadhguru said, if you are with me for one moment completely, we don't need this laptop, phone ,video , etc. I can initiate you just like that if you are ready. And I had tears flowing down my eyes continuously. I couldn't understand the emotion. I wasn't happy or sad but it was an explosion inside of me. Immediately, I requested Isha Yoga Center Coimbatore to allow me to take part in Bhava Spandana the following week on July 16th and by his grace, they did allow me, after which I immediately signed up for volunteering for BSP. Co incidentally, this was BSP for 2024 Sadhana Pada participants. I was so inspired by their energy levels. Volunteering opened up something new inside me as I had never volunteered/helped around anywhere before. Sadhguru has always surprised me and taken me for a ride and I just sit with him. I don't know how I am hoping to grow. I am someone who just jumps into things without any expectations. I just want to do more and more sadhana and seva and dissolve into everything.
column55: I think its the perfect schedule. In my experience of being an Ashram Program Volunteer in the past, I thoroughly enjoyed it. Not using my phone so much and reducing my words to 50% became so easy to practice, with the schedule given to me. It made me realize how much (for the lack of a better word) garbage was in my mind and activity everyday and how I was doing so many things compulsively. It made me a more conscious person.
column56: I am quite physically active and make sure I walk or run at least 2-3 kms a day. I have also started practicing Yogasanas, therefore, I'll be okay with everything.
column57: When I enrolled myself for BSP Volunteering, I definitely had some resistance towards some activities. We were taught a mantra and when I would recite it, doing anything and everything became so easy and blissful. Therefore, I am okay with any activity assigned to me.
column58: I studied in a Boarding School and there, it was a huge dorm of 60 people. I have already lived in spaces like that and I grew up to miss it. So, Im quite excited to be taken back to my school days!

There have been multiple job switches over the years. He worked for a year in BPO where he was handling technical customer issues in the front end. Then he worked for Tech Mahindra for 4 months as Sales Advisor & then quit. He again worked at various places didnt mention the name of the organizations. He felt that its all waste of time. Now since 2 years he has been playing Poker professionally both Online as well as Offline. Through Poker he is making his living.

He was very Good in Academics untill his 11th after which in 12th he dropped out. He joined Engineering (IT) then quit. Then joined MBA again quit. Due to societal pressure he somehow managed to complete BA in Psychology in 2021.

He has volunteered for BSP in July 2024. During Janamashtami he volunteered with the Aesthetics team & also has experience of volunteering in Biksha Hall & Akshaya. Never volunteered anywhere outside Isha.

He was very much involved during the call. He looked very Enthusisastic. At certain places I noticed he was scratching his head.He has always been travelling around be it for Education or due to Poker he traveled to Vietnam, Goa . Until 11th he was very good in Academics but after that he kept on jumping from one field to the other. He thought it was waste of time. Its not serving the purpose. The journey that he has gone through from his college it felt that he was unstable. He used to not write exams & would leave the paper blank because he felt that this piece of paper will not define him. Due to societal & family pressure he finally completed BA in Psychology from Pune. He then started playing Poker & till date he continues playing it. Poker is the source of income for him currently. He saw Sadhgurus video about IE & thought why not register for it & see what it does to him. In July 2024 he completed his IE. His experience was something beyond words & tears could not stop flowing out of his eyes. IE has made him much calmer ,able to sleep better & also his stamina has increased. He then immediately applied for BSP in the same month & completed it & then immediately applied for BSP volunteering . During BSP Volunteering he saw all Sadhanapada participants energy levels & got inspired. During the same time he saw people in Ashram doing Kaka Kriya so he didnt want to miss on it & immediately completed Shoonya Intensive. He has completed his Shambhavi Mandala. Only one evening he missed his Shambhavi practice till date. Learnt Yogasanas post Shoonya & has been practicing the same. He wants to come in this space & deepen his Sadhana & do as much as he can for this organization. Currently he is in Mumbai but has been travelling a lot around. Currently he along with his mom & sister staying in Mumbai. Father is working in Bangalore he got transferred there. He will be getting retired in a couple of years. Parents are very supportive of his participation in SP. Sister has completed IE & then learnt Yogasanas as well. He has given sisters contact details as emergency contact . Took his parents contact number. Father:9920713699
Mother:9769420235. Preferred language is English for the parents. The applicant is fluent in English & Hindi. Dad has BP & some issues with Back.
He has been visiting a counselor since school days & continued uptil 2016. His parents found him weird because he used to not write anything in his exams would leave the paper blank. There was no any medication given during the counselling sessions. It was just a conversation. Nothing Major. Loves to play football on weekends. Loves to travel around. Overall he looked really Stable during the call.
NA

He wakes up around 6am or 7am & does his Practices(Yogasanas,SCK,Shambhavi & Shoonya). He then has his breakfast & spends time in poker from 11am to 4pm. At 4pm he goes to gym for workout. Post 7pm he again spends time in playing Poker for 2-3 hrs. He goes to bed by 11pm/12pm.
He consumes Alcohol on occasional basis. Doesn't have the habit of drinking Tea/Coffee as he doesn't feel good. He was addicted to smoking right from 15yrs of age & in April 2024 he completely quit it. It took him some time to come out of his smoking habit. Since April 2024 is has not smoked & also doesn't have the urge for it.
