column36: Applicant is deeply touched by Shambavi and he could not understand how a 21 mins practice done for a short span of time can create such a transformation in him. He fees hes at the crossroads and want to dedicate his life in a meaningful way for spirituality and he feels SP is the way to bring about this transition. His wife had to be away for work for 5 years when his kids were very young and he had to take care of them like a mother. He really enjoyed the feminine side of him and he is sure SP will help him deepen his connection with the kids - He said he wanted to have a relationship with his kids - he said he wants to have "minimal conversation with maximum understanding". (Applicant had written a detailed list of reasons for why SP. We covered a few of them in detail during the call as well.)
column54:
There are various reasons to write about "Why this particular time". I will try to write down points. 
P1: 
I have been working in the Indian Space Research Organization(ISRO),Govt Of India as a scientist since 2001.For the last few years I have added my leaves one by one. And now is the time when I have sufficient leaves to complete the program as required for 7 months. I wish to invest my leaves for such a greater purpose where my life gets ready for time to come. 
 
P2: 
I have two daughters 9 year and 13 year old. Being a father of teenage girls, to understand them more closely, more clearly and especially to understand them with minimal or without any verbal communication, it is very much essential for me to know myself. This is a very crucial time of my life. A single slip of understanding between me and them may lead towards any direction. 
At the time of completion of this program in 2026 they will be turning 11 and 15 year respectively. I am 200% sure that Sadhanapada will help me to grow into a good human once I complete my inner journey. 
With active intervention in spiritual, emotional, and physical areas as Sadhanapada offers a structured environment for such transformation, providing tools, discipline, and a space to consciously work through these internal shifts, I will be able to contribute better in their life also along with my own. I can be a better version of myself to support my wife in the overall development of our family. 
 
P3: 
Sometimes, I feel that something is ‚Äúmissing‚Äù despite external accomplishments. 
Choosing Sadhanapada at this particular time will help me to tap into deeper layers of life beyond the material, to understand my true nature, and to explore the deeper questions of existence. 
 
P4: 
At this very moment I really feel a transformation in the inner core of myself towards a greater life. This is a turning point for me. I am at the crossroads of my life. Sadhanapada provides both the space and the tools for deep reflection, helping me to gain clarity about my life‚Äôs purpose and the path to take that leads towards a state of enlightenment. 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
Sadhanapada program, focuses on intensive self-transformation through yogic practices, discipline, inner work and seva. 
 
I would like share a part of my life from 2018 when my daughters were on 3 and 7 yers old. My wife had to shift Delhi from Ahmadabad for her office assignment. She was there for 5 years till 2023. Daughters, me, and a maid(for support) stayed in Ahmedabad. During this time when I was taking care of a three year old girl who still wear diapers and on her way of leaning phase of expressing herself in words, I realised that feminine part in side my male looking structure is very strong. She used to call me mother until her friends and social friend corrected her. 
I believe every male has some percentage of feminine nature in him. if I did not have this feminine layer in me then perhaps I would not have been able to raise my little daughters for so long. 
Sadhanapada for sure will nurture and nourish my feminine core. I hope it will flourish and bloom in multi dimension through the program. When I say "I am the mother to the world", I really wish to attain the level of MOTHER. 
 
 
 
P1: Through the program I hope to dive into deeper states of self-awareness and consciousness,understanding the nature of the self and the universe. Transcending the limitations of the mind and body to experience a deeper connection with life, beyond the material and ego- 
based identities. 
 
P2: Through the program I hope improvement in physical health and fitness through regular yogic practices like asanas, kriyas, and other physical disciplines. Development of better alignment, flexibility, and energy levels, experiencing the body as a more stable and vibrant force for life. 
 
P3: What I like the most is to live in harmony with a group, building a sense of community and contributing positively to a shared environment. Doing our own work and seeing all work as a 
spiritual practice. 
 
P4: I do believe that this program will strengthen my concentration through meditative practices,leading to sharper focus and less mental clutter. This will cultivate calmness in the face of challenges, reducing stress and emotional reactivity. 
 
P5: Last but not the least clear path for "Nirvana" and liberation from the cycle of life and death
column55:
I strongly believe that the structured schedule of Sadhanapada is designed to create an intense environment for self-transformation. As I am looking for a profound, focused journey inward(within), it could be deeply rewarding. 
This environment is designed to break habitual patterns, providing an opportunity for transformation. This is the most tempting part of the program. Adjusting to rules about diet, sleep, and conduct might be challenging initially so what? Following this schedule for sure will lead to the true end result and purpose of the program.
column56:
The physical demands of Sadhanapada serve as a powerful tool for growth, but they also present real challenges. They build resilience, physical endurance, and provide grounding. 
 
Walking long distances is not a concern. It's a regular practice for me. Walking around sacred and consecrated places help us to imbibe the energy transmitted in that area. This will prepare us for the rest of the day. 
 
Farming can be a little bit challenging as I need to re-learn it. After joining my job I am away from farming activity. Though I visit my farm on a regular basis and in touch with farming activities but due to involvement of different agriculture machines human interaction have reduced. I used take care of cows, providing food to them, cleaning their area, sowing, harvesting, preparing farm etc in my childhood till my college times. Farming keeps us grounded and connected with the earth element. 
 
Sitting cross leg is a part of daily life. We do our breakfast ,dinner and other daily activities at home in sitting position. 
 
Other activity like seva in Bhiksha Hall, kitchen, cleaning of ashram, volunteering at Dhyanalinga and Linga Bhairavi, other programs in the ashram, I strongly believe that it has a ripple effect on one‚Äôs capacity to handle challenges in other areas of life. The key is in embracing the discomfort as part of the process of breaking old patterns and developing inner strength.
column57:
Very truly stating that I have no such choice. 
I am OK with any volunteering activity. 
It may be physically intense(I may not be able to lift heavy weight alone) or office based. 
It may be cleaning toilets, sweeping or mopping, taking care of visitors, cutting vegetables, washing utensils and other kitchen. 
If there‚Äôs flexibility, i would like to explore different areas like gardening, cooking, volunteering in different departments, or other forms of seva (service), alongside my core practices. 
I like teaching. I can take science/maths/physics classes for kids. I did my M.Tech in Electronics Design and Technology. I can do seva in field of engineering, designing and development of construction area, model making, creating animations to explain science of spirituality. 
 
As a farmer i can be assigned farming activity for example water flow management,sprinkler,rain gun and other water management setup, more crop par drop farming, post harvesting crop management, natural farming, solar setup for sustainable energy.
column58:
I belong to middle class family. I have 6 sisters. I was brought in a small house. 2BHK house was shared in 11 members, 6 sisters, my grand repents, my parents and me. We had sliding beds shared by two members of family. When ever guest were at home, we used to sleep on floor. It may be summer or winter. We shared not only bed but blankets also. This is how I have lived for 17 years. This culture is still alive in family. As after marriage and two kids per family, we are grown to 30 member family [7(Sibling) x 2 (Spouse) =14, 14 kids(Youngest of 6year and Eldest of 28year, 6girls 8 boys) and 2 (my parents)]. Hence sharing facilities for 7 months will have no impact on my practice. Also I can take care of other participant by creating a comfortable sharing environment. Doing my own early morning activity on time. Leaving toilets and bathroom clean proper flush after use. keeping stay are tidy and clean. Not leaving unfolded bedding. 
 
One may think that sharing with siblings is easy where as sharing with unknown person from different culture or different part of world will be difficult. I believe when we stay together with shared common goal, sharing any other things hardly matres. During my hiking and biking camps, scout guide camps and other such activities I have shared facility.
column59:
I am doing Isha practices for a loang time and my family has seen the changes / benefits that it has brought to me. 
They are supportive to me in my current practices. 
I have discussed the details of this program to my family and they are ok with my stay in Ashram for 7 months. 
Also in the present day , the technology has reduced the gap, we can have video calls / live sessions so that the kids do not feel my absence.

column54: I‚Äôm seeking growth in clarity of mind, strength of body, and peace of spirit‚Äîa harmony that I feel would allow me to contribute to the world around me more fully and authentically. Sadhanapada, with its intensity and commitment, seems like a powerful catalyst for this growth.
column55: I understand that following a strict daily schedule with limited personal time, no days off, and fully adhering to the program's expectations and ashram guidelines will require significant discipline and commitment. While it sounds challenging, I see it as a necessary part of the transformative journey that Sadhanapada offers. By immersing myself in this structured lifestyle, I‚Äôm allowing myself to step away from familiar habits and comforts, which I believe can lead to greater inner clarity and growth.
column56: I feel both challenged and motivated by the physical demands of the program. Walking long distances, sitting cross-legged for extended periods, and engaging in activities like farming will test my physical endurance and adaptability. However, I see this as an opportunity to strengthen my body and to cultivate resilience.
column57: I am fully willing to be assigned to any volunteering activity, whether it is physically intense or office-based, for the full duration of the program. I understand that volunteering is an essential aspect of the Sadhanapada experience, and it will likely push me to step outside my comfort zone and develop new skills. Whether it involves physical labor, like farming or manual work, or administrative tasks in an office, I am ready to contribute with a mindset of service and humility. I see it as an opportunity to cultivate a sense of responsibility, patience, and teamwork, and I am committed to giving my best to whichever task I am assigned, as it is all part of the transformative journey.
column58: I feel open and receptive to sharing space with other volunteers, as I understand that it is a natural part of the Sadhanapada experience. While it may require adjustments, particularly in terms of personal space and privacy, I see it as an opportunity to cultivate patience, adaptability, and community spirit. Sharing a dormitory, communal bathrooms, and participating in group activities can foster a sense of unity and collective purpose, which is integral to the ashram environment.
column59: My family understands and supports my desire to attend Sadhanapada for the full duration of the program. They recognize that this experience is important for my personal growth, well-being, and spiritual journey. Although they may feel a bit concerned about my absence and the challenges I might face, they respect my decision and trust that the program will positively impact me. Knowing that I am pursuing something meaningful and transformative gives them confidence, and I feel grateful for their encouragement as I take this step.

column54:
I want to do sadanapada for the following reasons 
 
1. Develop clarity : After attending Samyama in December 2022, my life completely turned upside down. The experience has been too intense and mystical to even articulate. The old structure within me just crumbled. Nothing of mine remained. I became alien to myself. For the first time in my life, I didn't know what to do with my life except for the intense longing to rediscover my purpose and hasten my spiritual growth. Now I want to give my time and effort to develop clarity and direction within myself. 
 
2. Intensify sadana : Outside ashram, it is quite difficult to practice all sadanas regularly due to time restrictions, lack of committed atmosphere, schedule and support. In ashram, one can immerse fully in intense sadana because of highly energetic consecrated space, well structured schedule and support. I did intense sadana for a month during my samyama preparation and I saw immense change in terms of physical, mental, emotional and energetic aspects. If practicing intensely just for a month can give such great results, I wonder how drastic, immense and life changing, it can be if one practices intensely for 7 months! 
 
3. Consecrated space : Consecrated space can ignite one's energy system into different dimension and ultimate possibility. It helps one to lead concentrated and highly vibrant life. 
 
4. Strong foundation : I want to first build stable platform interms of body, mind, emotions and energy to explore the ultimate spiritual possibility. I want to develop unwavering focus, discipline and dedication. I want to be able to handle both big and small tasks or challenges without getting overwhelmed or stressed out. 
 
5. Spiritual growth : I have been an intense seeker of truth from a very young age. I have had many profound questions about the universe, life and the nature of reality. I have found answers to few of my questions after coming in contact with Sadhguru but many are still unanswered. I am rigorously and consistently searching answers through the yogic science. I want to know the very source of my life and the creation at any cost. I want to mature spiritually as fast as possible and explode into the ultimate possibility of being a human. 
 
6. Joy of volunteering : volunteering is a wonderful opportunity to offer oneself through action. Its a powerful process, where one can loosen up rigid personality structures, to become absolute willing and open to life. I want to grow beyond my limited likes and dislikes, ideas and opinions and become willing, flexible and open through selfless involvement. I want to be able to treat every action, whether it's small or big, with equal involvement and devotion. There is immense joy and satisfaction in volunteering. 
 
7. Poornanaga and bramhacharya : After samyama, I don't seem to find satisfaction and fulfillment in any of the activities concerning the outside world. A sense of incompleteness is growing within me as I try to involve more and more with the outside world. On the contrary, there is a deep sense of satisfaction and fulfillment in offering oneself as volunteer at ashram. In this two years period, I have developed a strong desire or inclination towards becoming full time volunteer and eventually may be brahmacharya. So I want to use sadanapada as a testing ground to see if it is the right thing for me.

Second call comments: Found SG on Youtube and then saw him at an event in london. Things started changing for him since then. He took up IE in person after this. We checked on aspects for culture shock, motivation for SP, knee pain and finances. On culture shock - he travelled to a few countries like Vienna, Italy, Czech Republic. Had spent close to a month in Italy travelling. Moved from Poland to London when he was 20, when asked about the cultural differences he said he was able to get used to it. Mentioned he will do the same with SP. Likes Indian food, started cooking with masala and spices. Motivation for SP: Stated he feels a longing for this. Previously he was more idle now after doing practices he sees he is better now - going for walks etc. Wants to make himself better. On finances he mentioned he has the amounts which he mentioned in his first call and when we stated that his savings will deplete due to coming for SP he mentioned that he doesn't have many commitments and only pays rent. His current stay is flexible and he will be able to move out his items to a relatives place if it is required. He travelled Italy for one year where he worked along the way to cover expenses. He seems to be living a lifestyle where finances are managed on an expense basis.

column54:
My name Shamprasad, I am not very good in public speaking or good in writing my thoughts. So I firstly ask sorry If I am writing more and if it is confusing. I heard about Isha yoga centre when I enrolled for pursuing Ph.D degree in biotechnology in Tamilnadu. I always wanted to do research that will help the society which is based on Indian traditional medicine. So I went to learn that in Tamilnadu being native of Banglore city. It was all going good until few years back maybe until 2021. I started noticing that I had reduced my self-confidence and not able communicate with people. From past one and half year I was in this confused mind. Then I started searching for yoga and meditation courses which I can learn in very less amount of fees. Because I don't have any good financial support. This year Feb when Sadhanapada program finished, there were lots of new and videos on youtube, after which once again I looked towards Isha yoga centre. Than I realised that, this kind of gurukula model meditation and training will help me to make better person and inturn I can come back to my path of self realization (what I am missing) . Than I went through may youtube videos, In one video, where a lady tells she was in confusion whether to go for MBA aboard or to go for Sadhanapada...?. After sadanapadha she realised that this was a life changing experience and she can face any situation and balance her mind. Like this few others experience motivated or I can say it was like my mind voice saying that this is which I was looking from many years. 
Than I enrolled in inner engineering after few months. I was inconsistent from earlier in any practice and that has been deeper so tightly that I alone cannot break it even after trying repeatedly. So I wanted something like this gurukula kind of system with continuously monitor and motivates to keepup my practice and do corrections where ever I do mistakes in practice. In today's world where money is required for learning and if no money no guidance, sadanapada program is the real hope for people like me I feel. I pray that this will be a foundation for my self realisation of what is my purpose and who do I fulfill the wish that I need to help the society which am I debt always. 
I think I have told what are the things I got in mind. Please forgive me if I hurt the feeling and emotions of the Isha yoga centre. I do always respect the for the effort they are making to bring better persons in everyone and makes a beautiful society. 
 
PRANAAMAGALU 
Dhanyavadha

column54:
I have been following Isha and Guru for 5 years, and Guru has completely changed my life, allowing me to find the ultimate purpose of my life. Guru has provided us with a comprehensive system to support us towards the ultimate goal. I have clearly defined my ultimate goal and am determined to continue moving forward. 
In order to reach the ultimate as soon as possible, following Guru and growing in the consecrated space of Guru is bound to be the fastest. So, I have been a long-term volunteer in Isha Institute of Inner-sciences for 3 months this year. I really, really enjoy the life of a long-term volunteer and enjoy every Seva team. In this process, the Seva accelerated my transformation and inner growth, and I can clearly feel the different stages of my growth. Meanwhile, I want to make something happen in the world with guru and isha. Then I wish to go through Sadhanapada. I can continue to be a long-term volunteer at the India center, and the environment there will definitely be better, allowing me to accelerate my conversion to ultimate and do more conscious things with guru and isha.

His wife started throwing tantrums that he is not spending enough time with her during SP. She went & spoke to Selvi Akka about this . Selvi akka called both of them & spoke to them. During SP 2022 one of the participant committed suicide. After that incident she started behaving weird & didnt want to stay here.His wife started saying that lets us go back. He didnt want to go back & told her if she doesnt want to go through the program then she can leave.She then visited clinic & told that she has suicidal tendency. Clinic called the applicant & told that its best you both take break go home & then come back. So after going back she didnt want to come back to ashram. When he decided to come back she called up Selvi akka & told that she cannot stay alone without him. So selvi akka called the applicant & told that you both first sort your issues & then think about the program. So that that was the reason he discontinued the program. Applicant & his wife didnt get along well so decided to part their ways. She never understood what Isha means to him. Both had difference of opinions. Both decided mutually to get divorced. Legally got divorced in April 2024. Applicant is still in touch with his wife whenever she needs any help she calls him. During his SP in 2022 he has supported in Tree care,Ishanga 7%,& Trained students for badminton at Isha home school.

Drinks Balck coffee. No alcohol,drugs ,smoking.

From there his perception bout life changed and he no longer interested in money. he got offer to be part of Ramakrishna mission in end of 2010. after coming out of ashram, he with others started NGO and working on providing free computer related coaching to village students in his village and nearby villages.

want to be part of whatever offered by Sadhguru and that tried to apply for SP and came to know that he need to complete IE. Didn't have enough money at that time.

column54: At the momemt, i am preparing for Silence Program in Jan. The Sadhana takes up momentum and i feel like i am going through bsp again. This speed of life feels very much needed, and i just really want to cultivate some balance that i can maintain intensity and sadhana, irrespective of situation. So i feel thst sadhanapadas schedule can help me moving towards being that person that whatever comes in future, i dont get thrown off by having a more intense work schedule or whatever comes. Life without the intensity of sadhana does not seem to benefit me and my enviroment as much, snd though i have been doing 4.5h of Sadhana daily before, i feel like with the samyama prep it changed in a way that suddenly people are really much enjoying working or being with me, and in whatever way, it transforms them too. So whatever i do after the pogramm, this is how it should be.

column54:
To be in a consecrated space, to be 100% involved in either Seva or Sadhana for a period of up to 7 months is all that seems essential in my life moving forward from this point. My sadhana practice would greatly benefit from this program and it would give my Sadhana a push in the right direction and that is the biggest investment I can make to my life now, before any investment to, my family, financial or professional life, I believe first must come a change in how I approach my Sadhana and I believe coming to such a consecrated space such as the Isha yoga center will be hugely beneficial. 
I hope to grow in terms of the following, I would like to deepen my sadhana, dedicate my time to Seva and let go of my personal preferences. Also, to adopt a new daily routine which will aid me in becoming a more effective life and possibility.
column55:
Early mornings are a joy when they start with a cold shower and Sadhana. I think little personal time will be something to get accustomed to but will happen naturally as I move through the program. Realistically, it will not affect my well-being in a negative way, only in a positive way. 
I am excited to adhere to any requirements and expectations since I am devoted to this cause and Sadhguru Ji. I will probably not want to leave the ashram so no problems there!
column56:
From a previous time where I walked a pilgrimage for 45 days walking on average 25 km per day (maximum. 33km a day) with no days off, carrying a 10km bag, I recall that it takes the body a little while to get accustomed to the new routine but once the body has caught up, it becomes like second nature. Furthermore, I have never shied away from strenuous physical activity, I enjoy it. 
I am used to sitting in a crossed legged position for the last 8 years, I have participated in the past in 3 Vipassana meditation 10 day programs, which also boasts a demanding schedule where I was sitting crossed legged for 10 hours a day. With regards to farming, it is a passion of mine.

My life is about breaking limitations and becoming more life. To be more joyful, vital and inclusive. 
I'm already progressing in that way and wish to get the extra support from the Sadhanapada program. 
I feel that it's the right time because I have built myself mentally during the last few years to be able and willing to go through such intensity that the program demands. I am staying in the IYC for a long time and life here suits me. 
I want to get to a place in my life where my experience is conscious and independent. I find life outside the Ashram more scattered and less supportive so I feel like I need some more time here to transform myself to a level where even if I'm outside and of the Ashram and I will choose the traditional course of university or work, it won't come as a compromise on my mental health and spiritual growth.

column38:
Back Pain : He had a Gym accident in 2021 while lifting weights (popping crack sound in his back. The pain was not excruciating but continued for a month. After doing Shambavi the pain reduced a lot. But whenever he rides his bike for long little bit of back pain comes back. 

His pain shot up was when he was parking the bike 3 months ago, he had another popping sound in the back and he could not walk for 3 hours. But he felt normal after. He did not visit the doctor or take any medication as he felt okay.

One week ago, when accompanying his friend for a doctor visit, he casually mentioned about his back pain to the doctor to understand the root cause. The doctor asked him to take x-ray, but they appeared to be normal. So doctor prescribed him Vitamin -D Tablets and a a tablet by name Olcoxib. (Hes not sure what its for though). 

He sometimes gets pain when he lifts something heavy (10 kgs). 

He mentioned he can sit for Shambavi without any pain. Apart from the above three situations, he has never had any pain.

Testicular Pain : He had slight pain in the testicles since Jan 2024. Doctor mentioned that it might be dur to leaving his testicles loose as he doesn't have the habit of wearing any underwear and asked him to wear it. Seems the doctor gave him some medicines for Blood clotting as well and He hasn't had any pain since August.

column54:
To make sense of my response, I want to give you a bit of my background. I have been doing job from past 15years and was married for 10yrs, always focused on building my career and making money. In late 2022 my wife got ill and was hospitalised where I spent all my time taking care of her getting all the medical help and all the prayers I could offer, but still after 3 months she passed away. 
The sudden grief hit me with a huge void, and that is when I started with Isha Kriya. When nothing was helping me, practising isha kriya helped me be sane and deal with my grief. With that I also stared with upa-yoga, which further helped me open up to myself and deal with the grief that I had, also giving me energy to get my motivation back to do the work. 
After that I completed my IE and got initiated to Shambhavi, which helped me be more happy and be grateful for the life. I was even able to help few colleagues with depression to get over it and also helping them to do IE program. It is almost an year now for me practicing the Shambhavi. People around me, my family and myself could feel the inner growth within myself which was never before. I started to have a different perspective of life. 
 
With all that transformation, it suddenly hit me that whatever I have done till now was just to full fill my desires but there is no limit to it. I now want to touch my inner most dimension. I want to contribute to upliftment of this world. For which I have to do things which I have never done before. But all of my life I have been filled with fear of failure, discrimination of the kind of work and many more which is holding me back to take steps that are necessary to help this world be a better place. 
I am currently in UK, leaving my job in March 2025, and moving back to India to enter the next phase of my life. Since, I don't have any kinds, my parents are in good health & living in India, and my only dependent was my wife (who passed away last year), I can now peacefully be part of the greater transformation through Sadhanapada and spend my time from May/2025 till the program lasts. Having earned all these years also provides me with the financial independence for that period. 
With Sadhanapada, I am hoping to get an environment where the demanding processes will transform me, grow my innerself, help me know my ownself through the sadhanas, surpass all comforts that is limiting me by doing all the yoga practices.
column55: I will be in full comfort at the time of death. Therefore while I am alive, I want to live with fullness. We look for personal time, days off, other distractions when we are doing something that we don't fully value. I am willing that is why I am applying for Sadhanapada. Therefore with agreeing to be part of the program, I am agreeing to follow the full schedule religiously and with full commitment. From waking up at 4:30am to eating only 2wice a day. I opted to be part of Sadhanapada for a purpose and if I continue following the same old habits, then the purpose of inner growth is defeated. The daily schedule not matching my own will make me open to learn new things, improve my perspective of life further. With no responsibilities, I can easily turn off my phone, be more available to the process and so that I can fully transform my life. I am fully prepared to follow the full guidelines to get the best out of this program.
column56:
In past I did 10 days of sadhana where I had to sit for 6hrs a day cross legged. I am always excited about connecting with the mother earth, therefore I frequently walk in nature for 7-10kms, do my shambhavi on sitting down on the floor. Although, I have not done that in for longer durations, therefore I know it is going to be demanding. 
As I am preparing myself for the next phase of the life, breaking my limitations and going beyond my current physical comfort is also a requirement. I want to connect with the nature however I can, be it walking, farming, or via sadhana by sitting cross legged on the ground. I am mentally prepared to do the same.
column57:
I have done volunteering where I have served others in food halls, made food in kitchen and cleaned larger areas after used by large public. Those activities end up giving me peace and inner happiness. 
Also, most of my life I have been working to fulfil my desires, which has created a lot of compulsions in myself which sometimes brings anxiety and unhappiness. I want to break free from my own compulsions, therefore I am willing to do any work that is needed, which will help me understand the different perspective of life, break my own mental blockers and help me support the community and the nature.
column58:

Having others who are on the similar path truly helps the individuals like me motivated everyday.

column54: In my early twenties, I had planned to attend Sadhanapada, but life had other ideas. I got sidetracked by the trivialities of daily life, and entangled in matters that were neither necessary nor meaningful. If someone asked me to pinpoint a specific reason for this detour, my honest answer would be, 'I don't know.' I feel a deep need to participate in this program now, as I believe it will help me gain a greater understanding of life. At this moment, I feel burdened by my own existence and I don‚Äôt want to be a burden to my own life. I want to transition from merely being alive and conscious to being consciously alive. This program feels like a crucial step toward that transformation.

column36: Akka is doing freelancing now. She said she will not take any projects if she comes here

Can call for parental consent after Nov 6th as they are travelling right now. Prefers tamil speaking Vol
Since she is been working for quite sometime she has sufficient saving to manage during that 7months.

She was been married to two years now and it was a arranged marriage. She said they were not getting along well. Her husband is doing business and doesn't spend time with family and not a family oriented guy. They don't have kids Since it was disturbing both of them and their family they mutually decided to get separated. Their divorce is going on right now and akka mentioned by April 2025 the legal proceedings with be over. No physical presence will be involved after that. She was emotionally stable when we spoke about this and she didn't have any hesitation to share these details when asked.
She has done Program Volunteering (BSP) and MSR volunteering for three years. Apart from that she is also supporting local center now with Gramotsavam.
She joined call on time. She presented herself well and was confident. Seemed like she was more aware about the schedule and other aspects of ashram like dress code and food.
Her father took home loan on her name but it will closed in next two months. Before she comes here that will be closed.

column36:
‚úî She has well-paid job, apartment, nice life, all comfort and convenience, but is looking for profoundness as she has the urge to do something deeper with her life ever since she started her journey with Isha. She is looking at SP as tool for breaking her limitations and resistance towards unpleasant or uncomfortable life situations and deepen her already ongoing practice and spiritual path. 
‚úîShe knows people who went through the program, and she saw their transformation and glow after programs. She wants the same. She didn‚Äôt apply sooner as she felt insecure about money/apartment/job to come to India for a long time. But now, she feels it is the right time, and she is fully ready, and she went through all other programs as preparation and is 100% sure she could make this commitment to come to SP
‚úî IE ‚Äì finished 2021 online. Sadhguru deeply touches her, and since she started doing practice (as soon as it was available), she feels like she started to live life and that that was the best decision of her life. She is more comfortable in difficult situations, has more joy and energy during the day, is more balanced, and can focus more on solutions instead of anger. 
‚úî Did all Isha programs; only Samyama left, and she is doing practices every day.
column54: I have a well paid job, a nice apartment, good relationships with friends and family. Everything that is considered a "good life". But there is something very much missing which I would call as profoundness, for lack of better words. Although, I have all this comfort and convenience, the urge to do something really worthwile and existentially valuable with my life is burning within me for few years now. I noticed that all this comfort and "security" is making me dull and creates more and more limitations/boundaries and resistance towards new things/changes in my life. For example, the thought of loosing my job causes so much anxiety and stress within me, as if there would not be any other possibilties in my life than this particular job. I realized, that I am really loosing my flexibility and agility to mold myself in different "shapes" as situations change. And this emptiness which all this causes in me reached a point where I clearly see/feel that it is not acceptable anymore. I am burning to explore the nature of me as a human being in its fullest depth and dimentsion and shift my focus completely inward. I am definitely determined to gain my flexibility and freedom back, which I had as a child. I don't want to live on the surface anymore and only experience deeper dimensions when I am volunteering or doing any activity with Isha. I want this profoundness and joy in my daily life. I think using Sadhanapada as tool for breaking my limitations and resistance towards unpleasant or uncomfortable life situations would make the change that I want to create.The structure that is given in the program would definitely be a huge support to keep up the motivation, enthusiasm and energy to keep going. Also having fixed times for guided Sadhana together with all participants gives a great boost to stick to the commitment to take up and of course complete the program. I'm striving to live a fullfilled, profound life which is worthwhile for myself and others around me. I am willing to commit and give myself to the process of the program and make use of everything which is given by Sadhguru and the energized space in the Ashram. I am willing to confront/overcome my gratest fears of insecurity and uncomfort of giving up my life as I know it till now and fully be present in the program for the whole duration whatever it takes. Never before in my life I felt so cristal clear that now is the time to invest in my inner growth and to do whatever is needed for it. I have the vision that I take up this path and stay for long term volunteering and become a Pournanga in the Ashram. Sadhanapada program is my first step towards this larger "goal" of mine.
column55: It will challenge me a lot to stay open and accept all situations that are occuring and overcoming the resistance withing me. But also I know that if I'm willing to grow I can handle everything with joy and go through the program without struggle. Since I am also a very structured person and following a kind of schedule in my daily life, I can apapt to the strict daily schedule and fixed times for different activities. I'm familiar with the guidelines of staying in the Ashram as I have been there already, so this is not a problem.

There will definitely be challenging times where my body would feel week or sth. but overall I'm quite confident that I can manage.

I will be completing my postgraduation in february 2025 and can dedicate completely for the program. I will be a bachelor without any financial burden and my family members are not financially dependent on me. 
This opportunity might not be there later on as i think i might get caught up with social and personal things. 
 
In terms of growth, 
i would like to become strong, agile and increase my stamina physically and would like be able to go and come down velliangiri hill without going out of breath like the local people there. 
 
Mentally i would like to have a stable mental balance in all situations so that everyday its not a turmoil to go through life. 
i have always struggled to maintain an inclusive emotion while i work. i would like to change that, so that i can keep my emotions always pleasant irrespective of the situation i am placed in. 
 
Spiritually or energywise i would like to just reach my fullest potential . Not growth, i would like to transform and mutate while i am in Sadhanapada . 
 
Lastly i would like to complete Samyama with sadhguru while i am in Sadhanapada.

column54:
Namaskaram, as I fill this form... I've been in the Ashram for 46 days exactly. And I'm staying for 50 days. I came here with a plan to complete my Shambhavi Mandala. It was my only goal, along with volunteering. Nothing else. I finally ended up doing it. I also learned Angamardhana and am about to finish the Mandala too. That's the impact of 50 days. I can't wait to look forward for 7 months of disciple and Sadhana. For real. Genuinely. I applied last year too - due to personal reasons I couldn't do it. I never filled the form also. So 2025 - now I'm keen and clear. In a way - I feel I'm better prepared now too. My shambhavi done. I volunteered too. Now I actually know the feel of it. So no regrets for missing out on last year. 
 
Having said all of this. To mention as main pointers. 
1) Routine & Disciple & Satvic Food & Mainly Sadhana & Life Lessons 
 
2) Always wanted to do this in my lifetime. Not sure what life later will look like, I can invest the time now. And I don't at all want to miss the opportunity. 30th year - with Sadhanapada! 
 
3) I feel I'll get more clarity than what I have now. 
 
4) If possible I also want to work on safety and self defence for women segment along with Sadhguru and Isha 
 
5) Sadhguru Darshan! My brother always says... we have a living Guru, it's our blessing. So I want to do it and experience it during that era 
 
6) Most Importantly I look at my life as an Adventure & Experiment... these 7 months. The person I can become & the Sadhana is what I really look forward too. Breaking the limitations. Boundaries. Thought Pattern. Working on the Inner Nature.

column54: Before doing Inner Engineering I did not think I'd have the time to learn any more practices, I thought Shambhavi would be more than enough for me. But once I started practicing Shambhavi, I had the urge to do more programs. I started volunteering for local city center activities and could not stop going for more. With each program, and each volunteering activity I kept breaking some limitation in me. I am a much more capable version of myself compared to the person I was before Inner Engineering. I have wasted so much of my life trying to get somewhere or achieve something. I think I have found everything I need in Sadhguru and I do not want to waste any more time of this very short life. I wish to enhance my ability to experience life, I want to make myself more established and settled within myself. Without settling the chaos within me, I do not think I am of any good use to myself or anyone around me. I wish to go through Sadhanapada to establish myself, to settle my inner chaos, to break my limitations, and be more useful and available for myself and the people around me. I am certain the consecrated space in ashram is going to be a tremendous support in this transformative process.
column55: A strict schedule that will be completely dedicated to Sadhana and Seva is going to be very conducive for my growth. Having very little personal time might be a challenge initially, but hopefully, I will be freed from that limitation within me. Strictly adhering to the requirements and expectations of the program will be the most beneficial for me above anyone else. And finally, I am looking forward to staying in the ashram and living the ashram way.
column56: I am comfortable with the physical demands of the program, it may be challenging initially but with consistent Hatha Yoga practices the physical limitations will be taken care of.
column57: I am willing to do any kind of activity my Guru thinks is needed for my growth.
column58: It will be a challenge to share dormitory stay areas and bathroom facilities. Although I have stayed in shared rooms and hostels previously, but with age you tend to start getting set in your ways and start seeking more privacy. I am aware this is a limitation in me as well, it would be very freeing to break this limitation.
column59: I have my parents and my elder sister in the family. My sister and my mom are completely on board with me staying in the ashram. My father is on the fence, he understands how important one's spiritual growth is but he doesn't completely agree with anyone spending so long in the ashram. My sister did Hatha Yoga Teacher Training in 2023, he wasn't on board with the idea initially but he came around in some time. I understand that owing to his old age he is seeking support from his children, for which my sister and brother-in-law are completely available to take care of anything that may be needed while I am in the ashram.

column11: ‚óè Developed a Database Manipulation Tool using Java Struts2, reducing human errors and manual intervention. ‚óè Built an Inspection Tool with Java SpringBoot and Hibernate, aiding field technicians in repairs. ‚óè Created a Monitoring Tool in Java Struts2 to ensure data flow between servers, integrating SMTP for email alerts.

‚óè Designed and implemented microservices architecture, enhancing scalability and maintainability. ‚óè Developed REST APIs with Java using SpringBoot, ensuring global exception handling and comprehensive unit tests. ‚óè Utilized GitHub for version control and conducted occasional code reviews to maintain code quality. ‚óè Managed CI/CD pipelines with TeamCity, ensuring seamless deployments and integrated GitHub Webhooks. ‚óè Deployed applications to Pivotal Cloud Foundry, leveraging both predefined and user-provided services. ‚óè Migrated database and set up Jenkins pipelines for seamless data transfer from GCP PostgreSQL to MS SQL. ‚óè Transferred CSV reports to/from Google Cloud Storage Buckets using Java.

column36: He is an SPS Inshanga and an Isha Local Center Representative. He has wanted to come for along time but life situations have not been right. In the year he got selected he got Covid and was into quarantine so he missed the last batch of SP. After that next year there was a tax issue (details in legal) and then financial constraints. He wants SP to help him build discipline with his sadhana and also because he doesn't find his work as fulfilling. He likes volunteering.
column38: At 27 he got chest pain, his doctor told him it was nothing.
column54:
Namaskaram, I was initiated to shambhavi in 2017, and have seen immense benefits in all aspects of my life due to it. However, whenever the work stress increased, my sadhana continuity broke, also under extreme work conditions external factors again started affecting me, these cycles have happened a few times now, in past 5 years. I want to learn to keep doing my sadhana with utmost intensity even in a very busy schedule and want to be as balanced as possible under any kind of external situation. 
 
I have been in phases where the sadhana is happening beautifully and I am in complete balance, but the growth has been slow, as whenever work pressure increased, I was not able to maintain my sadhana intensity. Last MSR 2024 volunteering in security team was an eye opener, during the volunteering I was able to perform my activities, which were very challenging and new for me effortlessly, without any impact on me, the balance I felt for a few months after the MSR volunteering was what I have been looking for.
column55:
For the sadhana to intensify and for me to gain a transformative sense of balance and clarity, i think the strict daily schedule is needed, and I am confident I will be able to follow it. 
 
Since all aspects of the program schedule are designed for personal growth, it is worth sacrificing the personal time. Anyways the most important aspects of my current usage of the personal time is already covered in the schedule, like sadhana, food and seva. Minimising mobile usage is something I would love to make a habit. If possible not using it at all for entertainment. Only using it if any activity is to be performed. 
 
In my current schedule, I have office work mostly morning 9 am to evening 9 pm and weekends I do local center Volunteering activities, so no days off is perfectly fine, since it's for volunteering, whatever be the activity. 
 
Staying in the ashram for 7 to 8 months will not be a concern, My parents are independent and i am single, so there is no urgent dependencies, i have been planning for financial backup for this for last 3 years, so now I am ready with that as well.
column56:
I enjoyed the barefoot walks I did all day during the 10 days of my volunteering for 2024 MSR volunteering. Since it was in security team, we had to go for long walks for rece of the points. Only crossing the metal bridge during the afternoon sun was a challenge, rest all made me feel more fit and energetic. 
 
Even as a participant for grace of yoga in 2022 MSR, even though shuttle service was provided, i preferred and enjoyed walking barefoot to the halls. 
 
I am used to going for long treks with local Isha Meditator friends, once in 3-4 weeks. These are on an average 5 to 8 km treks. 
 
Over the years I have been able to sit more time comfortably cross legged, as of now I am able to sit around 1 hr to 1.5 hrs comfortably cross legged, I want to improve this. 
 
Since I get to work from home, during farming season many times I stay in Mangalore my hometown and volunteer wherever possible with farming activities at my familial farms. After volunteering for save soil to conduct sessions for students, I have also myself become more aware of the deep relationship between soil health and plant health, and i practice the learnings of this daily in my small but beautiful balcony gardens, would love to show some pictures of the produce. I also manage a composting setup of 30 liters in my balcony to process daily kitchen waste, this has been running successfully for last 3 years. Also have been teaching it to Isha meditator friends, some have replicated it at their home.
column57: I am completely willing to be assigned to any activity that needs my service for the full duration of the program.
column58: I am perfectly ok with sharing space with others. This will be a good test of my sadhana. I did not find this a concern at all during my 10 days of MSR volunteering and BSP participation as well.

Tax not legal around 2021: He bought a home in India when he was in Singapore and did not file a tax return in India since he was filing in Singapore. Since work had been hectic there he had ignored the notice he got so it had reached a point where they were like pay the 10-15 lakh upfront and then we will negotiate. It has all been resolved now

His SMK practice is correct. He has finished the mandala. Due to work there have been periods where his practice gets irregular. He used to wake up at 7-8 am. By the end of his SMK mandala he started waking up at 5-5:30 am. SMK made him naturally want to stop eating fish. It also opened him up he became more compassionate to his family and random strangers. He also got less angry and frustrated. He used to get angry if food is spicy or there is less salt in it for example. He has not had any outbursts of anger in the last 6 years. He does not blame anyone else anymore.

Volunteering gives him satisfaction and helped him break his limitations of talking to strangers and not being able to drive.

column54: I would like to go through the Sadhanapada program to live those 7 months completely involved in doing whatever is necessary of me in the ashram without any reason like getting a paycheck, earning a living, ect. This will help me apply that to life outside the ashram and simply go through life without any dependency/attachment but experiencing the present moment 100%. I‚Äôm also looking forward to an opportunity to do the practices I learned so far every day without any distractions and deepen my experience with them. I‚Äôm hoping the daily schedule will also help me gain some discipline. If I do something for 7 months straight such as waking up early, I‚Äôm hoping it will become a habit which I can continue after the program as well.
column55: I am completely happy to follow a strict daily schedule. If I don‚Äôt see what I am doing as a painful assignment then it should not matter whether I get a weekend or not. Everyday should feel like a ‚Äúweekend‚Äù. The guidelines of staying in the ashram such as the vegetarian diet, 2 meals a day, attire and conduct are not new to me so I don‚Äôt feel that it will be an adjustment. Even if something is new to me I am flexible enough to adapt to a new situation and adhere to the guidelines and culture of the ashram and the locality.
column56: During summer I usually go on a walk for about 3-4 km. My current work as a dentist is also physically demanding where I am constantly switching between dental chairs to see about 25-30 patients in a day doing fillings and extractions. During COVID I was in a dental college where we had 2 mouth masks on from 8am-5pm walking up and down a staircase carrying dental instruments (we were not allowed to use an elevator which was reserved for patients at that time). We were working through lunch so most of the days the only meal we had was dinner after coming home. Sometimes we were not even drinking water throughout the day because it would take extra time to remove the face shield, mouth mask, ect. Initially it was very challenging and I found myself stopping for a minute while going up the stairs. I would get very hungry and a little weak but eventually my body got adapted to it and even felt more energetic after I got used to the routine. I lost about 11-12kgs over the span of 9 months. I am sure this program will be just as challenging physically. Even if it a struggle initially I am sure my body will adapt to what is required of me. I will also try to prepare by exercising consistently and sitting cross legged at home.
column57: I am happy and willing to volunteer wherever I am needed for the full duration whether it is physically intense or office based.

I don‚Äôt feel that this particular time holds any unique significance for joining Sadhanapada; any time is as good as any other to embark on this journey. I am simply applying now. 
 
I don‚Äôt have specific expectations. I am open to whatever experiences come my way‚Äîespecially those beyond my mind and therefore outside the scope of my imagination. I understand that my growth will depend on the effort. dedication, and openness that I bring to the program.

column54: I will be graduating in June 2025. Before pursuing further education, I aim to cultivate a sense of clarity, balance, and stability within myself. Before I decide what to do in life, I wish to make sure that all immediate and temporary pressures and compulsions are dealt with. Apart from that, I also wish to touch as many lives as possible with Sadhguru's vision. Hence, I feel Sadhanapada will be apt for me at this time.
column55: I understand that the program‚Äôs schedule is crafted by Sadhguru, and is intentionally designed to maximize its impact in helping us overcome limitations and think beyond our personal identities. I understand the importance of limited personal time and the absence of days off to support our sadhana, and I am fully committed to adhering to the guidelines and expectations.
column56: I understand that the physical demands of the program, such as walking long distances and sitting cross-legged are a part of the transformative process. These activities not only test physical endurance but also challenge mental blockages. Even though it might take me a few weeks to get physically accustomed to the intense levels of activity, I‚Äôm prepared to embrace them in my growth and inner discipline.
column57: I wish that I could serve the ashram and the meditators to the best of my physical and mental capabilities. I wish to contribute to Sadhguru's mission of a conscious plant. Hence, I am willing to take up any volunteering activity for the same.

He currently lives with roommates in the hostel and will easily be able to adapt and is easy going with people. Discipline and schedule is what he is looking forward from the program and he is committed to that. He worked as a Forest Beeat officer for 4 years till 2023 and easily walks 10-15 kms.

After graduating his BSc in 2019. He was a Forest Beat Officer for about 3-3.5 years in a preserved forest. He mentioned though he liked the job in terms of living in the forst and spending time away from city, residents etc, there was almost no work throughout the day and he felt he was wasting his time. So he quit his job and started his masters.

He mentioned he did not go to school till age 13 and directly enrolled for 9th std but was able to pick up everything. He did is BSc (Botant, zoology,chemistry) {he confirmed that it was the name f the degree]. from 2016-2019. He is currently doing his MSc in cognitive neurosciece since 2023.

His parents are very young (Dad 45 and mom 43). He was born when his father was 18. His younger sister (23) is married and lives about 3-4 kms away from his parents. His parents are into agriculture. they do farming with a 3 acre land and also have some cattle. He mentioned his father is very supportive for all his decisions and through he doesnot know much about Isha , meditation etc, he is fine with him taking a break and coming for SP.
He has some savings from his work and his parents will also be able to support him. His parents are healthy and are financially independent.
No legal concerns

column36: Anna is working as an associate lawyer intern and a financial analyst or stock trader on the side. These are the professions he can work and quit whenever he wants according to him. So, If he gets into Sadhanapada he's going to quit being a lawyer for the whole duration of the program and also quit trading while he is here in the ashram. He can resume both when he goes back.

From the webinar, He is looking forward to experience the lifestyle of the ashram. His current challenge is to sit in ardha-siddhasana for longer times. He is able to sit for 30 to 40 minutes without any issues but cannot sit more than that. 

He has sounded flexible for all the aspects of the ashram as he has volunteered for Linga seva for 10 days and has seen most of the ashram. He has also got some positive feedback from current SP24 participant (Neeraj Singh). 

When he has legal case, Anna has to dedicate 12-16 hours of focused time sometimes, so he said he is able to adjust to any kind of schedule here.

Anna graduated in LLB in 2020. He started as an associate lawyer in Supreme Court of India under a senior lawyer and then move to work for a company for some time and then move back to Supreme Court of India under a different senior lawyer this time . She was interning basically in different roles . She took a break of one or two months in between after his graduation till now . 

Apart from LLB, Anna has a diploma in corporate governance and finance which is based on capital market and stock trades. So he also trades stocks on the side parallelly being a lawyer. 

Anna has also done a three month course on Digital marketing and also as a diploma on national Stock Exchange related to capital market.

Anna's hobbies include going on Trek whenever possible. He has visited Himalayas, Vaishno Devi temple twice, Kedarnath, surpass trek in Himachal Pradesh.

Anna has done Bachelor of Law from Pune University and graduated in 2020. He has interned under a senior lawyer, worked for a company and again moved to work under a different senior lawyer this time maintaining his continuous work experience after his graduation.

Anna is fluent in Marathi, Hindi, English.

His father approves his involvement with Isha and him going to Sadhanapada. Father also has been a lawyer and he is self-sufficient and is not dependent on the applicant. Anna's mother passed away few months ago with the liver disease and he has a younger brother who is also a trader in capital market, B.S.E grad, and earns his own money too. Since applicant also is a lawyer and is self-sufficient there is no dependency in terms of expenses.

We can give a consent call to his father to confirm if there is a physical dependency.

Anna's mother has passed away 6 months ago. His father is a lawyer, and his brother is a trader, and both are self-sufficient by themselves. Anna has some savings from being a lawyer as well as trading in the stock market, so he is self-sufficient and not dependent on the family and the family is also not dependent on him as well.
None

No exclusive walking/jogging in a day.

Ever since he has been practicing Shambhavi daily and went for MSR sadhana, the online 21 day yoga challenge and Bhairavi sadhana. The tight guidelines and intensity of these practices were challenging for him at first but going though them showed him how he really enjoys and desires to live an active life.
 ‚Ä¢ He learnt about life in the ashram and SP talking to other volunteers from his local center and feels that after completing his studies and he wants to focus on his wellbeing and learn new yoga practices to live life at the maximum intensity.

column54: I was searching videos of self-improvement and how to manage stress and anxiety on YouTube, and then I found Sadhguru's videos back in 2021. Slowly, I started watching more and more videos by Sadhguru. I tried Isha kriya and meditation, but it was not regular. In 2022, I got to meet an Isha meditator who was my senior in college. I told her my wish to participate in Sadhguru's program. Then she told me about Bhairavi Sadhana. When I read the guidelines of Bhairavi Sadhana, at first I thought I could not follow these guidelines. But I wanted to give it a try, and I was able to do 21 days of Bhairavi sadhana without any problem. Then I did Mahashivaratri sadhana. After this, there was no looking back. I wanted to participate in more programs by Isha. I did my inner engineering in June 2023 in Pokhara. Then I did Bhairavi Sadhana and Mahashivaratri Sadhana 2024. I also did Pancha Bhuta Kriya Online 2024. I have been doing sambhavi mahamudra kriya daily since the day of initiation. I got to know the advanced programs by Isha, and ever since I want to take part in advanced programs. I got to know about the Sadhanapada program from Sadhguru. I did some research about the program, and it became clear to me that I want to participate in this program. At that time, I was a third-year undergraduate student. Then I decided to wait for the 2025 Sadhanapada program, as I will have graduated from college and there would be no family pressure. So, here I am applying for Sadhanapada 2025. I have decided this is the time to work on my inner wellbeing and intense my sadhana. There are many reasons why I wish to go through Sadhanapada. I want to experience life in that intensity as in Sadhanapada. I want to be at my guru's abode. I want to experience volunteering at Isha Yoga Center. I want to experience living around consecrated spaces. I really want to experience life at its maximum, and I am hoping Sadhanapada will help me in that direction.
column55: I think the strict schedule will help to intensify my sadhana, and I can follow the schedule . I am living somewhat like that schedule right now. I am ready to follow the guidelines for staying in the ashram. I don't think the daily schedule and Ashram's guidelines will be a problem for me.
column56: I consider myself a physically active person. I play football and cricket regularly. I go trekking and hiking regularly. I walk a lot as well. I have a farming background. column57: Whatever volunteering tasks I will be assigned to, I am willing to do that, whether it is physically intense or office based.
column58: I am comfortable sharing space with many other volunteers. Sharing space will not be an issue for me.

column54:
I completed Hatha Yoga teacher training in 2023. At the end of 2023, I set out to try teaching Isha Hatha Yoga in Germany. However, I quickly realized that while I am someone who practice, I don‚Äôt feel the need to talk about it or encourage others to follow the same path. Additionally, I encountered resistance in the very rational German society toward what I was doing. So, teaching soon lost its purpose for me. After my return from India, not only did teaching fail to work out, but all the other activities I tried to establish to make a living independently also did not succeed. 
 
After months of struggle, I applied for my old job‚Äîa job I had promised myself never to return to before starting Hatha Yoga teacher training. That was about three months ago. For me, doors in Germany remained closed, which made me recall what Sadhguru had said when he came to the Hatha Yoga school during training. He said that if teaching didn‚Äôt work out, one should come back to the ashram. For some reason, those words stayed in my mind the whole time. 
 
When it became clear to me that returning to the ashram was my only path, I spoke with Lokendra Anna from the Hatha Yoga school and sought his advice on the best way to return as a long-term volunteer. After listening to me, he said the best option would be to do Sadhanapada. So I applied shortly after.

column54:
I have been thinking about to take Sadhnapada program from some time but then after attending a few advanced programs, I wondered if I was ready to take Sadhnapada due to very disciplined lifestyle and strict schedule. But this thinking over time was turned into strong desire to go through this program as I am at a stage in my life although having a successful career and reaping all the benefits of a comfortable lifestyle, still makes me feel vacuous in terms of life experience as If I need to experience something different and new which my current lifestyle isn't offering anymore and something needs to change. 
 
From my previous experience in situations and circumstances looking backwards on reflecting these were the situations which made me strong, wise but also gave me a deeper experience of learning of life, I learnt that as a person I have potential which uncovers with not just difficult situations but also with wonderful moments in life. 
 
Sadhnapada is definitely a program which will enable me to not to just of being service to others but also go through different dimensions of life experience. I won't have this opportunity to be among people who have gathered for the same cause and are willing to give themselves into service, I am sure I will have lot to take away from which I won't have otherwise, in my mundane life routine which is so monotonous and unidirectional.
column55:

I am curious that program will make my sense of personal freedom grow to bring more discipline and schedule in my lifestyle. I am looking forwards to get clarity and sense of balance in my life.

column54: I had been planning to join the Sadhanapada in the last 2-3 years. This particular time would be the best for me as I am able to take care of other things in my life (ie. work, finances, mortgage, family). This experience had given me a glimpse of what to expect in a program like Sadhanapada. I am hoping that there will be a lot of limitations within myself that will come up during the program so that I can clearly see where I need to work on myself. I also hope that by doing the practices daily, being in a consecrated environment and having the support of people walking the same path that I can develop the clarity that I need to be able to overcome my limitations.

Parents have been part of Radha Swamy for the last 8-10 years and her dad used to listen to Osho and talk about Karma, spiritual talks, Yogasanas etc. Her brother first saw Sadhguru on YouTube and got inspired while in Germany. He introduced Akka to IE and she got initiated into IE in April2024.
She started with Sadhguru videos by herself initially and soon her partner also joined her to watch together. 
She always wanted a good life but was never ambitious, but Sadhanapada felt ambitious and worthwhile. She wants to delve deeper and make use of the conducive atmosphere while she is here.

column54:
Multiple reasons, first and foremost being I don't have any undeniable obligations at this point since I'm not married, I'm not working a full-time job but freelancing, my parents are healthy and financially independent, and I have comfortable savings to be out of work for some time. 
Secondly, with the growing interest in Isha, access to the ashram will become inevitably hard, and I want to spend some time in the ashram to be with Dhyanalinga. 
Thirdly, while my practice is concrete and I don't struggle with the dilemma of doing it or not every day, I think this is the right time to take it up a notch.
column55: I think I'm ready for this. I tried something similar last year but just for 3 days- I stayed in a monastery in Thailand, volunteering, and following a strict schedule. While challenging at first, I had a really good time and found the experience quite valuable. I truly like being in the ashram and I want to closely experience the life of a renunciate even if briefly so.
column56: I'm quite comfortable walking long distances. I've been living on and off in Himachal Pradesh and Uttarakhand for the last 2 years, and that has helped me get used to being on foot a lot, sometimes even with my rucksack. I'm very comfortable sitting cross-legged and can sit for long hours, even in Padmasana. I've never done farming, but I'm fairly active outdoors and am used to physical activity- so shouldn't be a problem.
column57: I understand volunteering isn't about preferences, and I am willing to try any activity. My parents have taken me to RSSB (Radhasoami Beas) Seva since childhood and I'm used to doing whatever's needed as part of Seva.

column59: Both my parents are initiated into the RSSB (Radhasoami, Beas) and have been doing their practices for around 8-10 years now. My brother has been an Isha Sadhaka for 3 years now. So my family is only happy to see me making progress on this path.

column36: He has a social media promotions business that he has taught his wife how to manage.

Every 2-3 months he and his family walks barefoot for govardhan yatra 21 km. He has tried waking up at 4 am but failed. He feels that new people, new environment and waking up may be challenging in he 1st 2 weeks but he will adjust. He said that he is coming here for seva as a sevak so he is willing for whatsoever the task is.

Initially he did a job in advertising when internet boomed he moved to the internet. In 2021 his business collapsed because his partnership broke and his partner took away the clients with good words. That was stressful but he pulled himself back up and continued. He has a social media promotions business.

He is 12th pass. His BCom degree is private which means he only went to give exams. He can stitch with a stiching machine. He has stiched boy's shorts. His mom has worked as a ladies tailor. He loves playing cricket. But now he doesn't play much as everyone is married and busy. He can speak, read and write in Hindi and English.
He lives with mother, wife and 1 year daughter. His father is dead. They are supportive as they have seen the changes SMK has brought in him. His wife is a professor in college
He has rented shops and houses

When he was in school there was an FIR against him because of boys fighting but they managed it and reached a resolution. He has tickets of car overspeeding and traffic light that he will pay off this week.

He has done SMK 4 times to perfect his practice. First time he did not follow through with shambhavi mandala because he did not understand how breathing can change a human. Second time he learned he did the mandala in 2022-2023. Third and Fourth time he did IE so that he can get corrections in his practice. Like he learned that he does not have to hold his breath when he is in a posture in nadi vibhajan. At the end of Shambhavi he gets emotional because it feels very good. He holds Koombhaka for 20s and Shoonyaka for 10s.
When he learned Angamardana recently he lost 12 kg in 3 months because of that. 

In volunteering he has managed events like marriages in family

He was well prepared for the call and seemed like someone who has the necessary enthusiasm and commitment to go through SP. He and his wife hope to put their daughter in Samskriti after 8 years or so.
He recently paid off loans.

Between active and sedentary. He wakes up 6-7 am. Drops his wife to college. Starts his day with neem, turmeric and honey in warm water. Finishes angamardana and SMK and walks on the terrace. At noon he has satvik food cooked by his mom. This is the only meal he has. Then he works on his business through his phone. At night he drinks a glass of triphala and sleeps. That takes away his hunger. Seems like he is committed to losing weight.

column54:
I'm looking to join Sadhanapada because I feel there‚Äôs more to life than just chasing goals and achievements. I want to understand myself better and find a sense of calm and clarity that isn‚Äôt easily shaken by everyday problems. 
 
Through this program, I hope to learn practices that help me manage stress, handle life‚Äôs ups and downs with a steady mind, and become a more positive, balanced person. My goal is to find a deeper purpose and inner strength that will help me live life with a sense of peace and kindness, and to share that positivity with others.
column55:
I understand that Sadhanapada has a very strict daily routine, with almost no personal time, no days off, and strict rules to follow in the ashram. I see this as a way to push myself beyond my usual habits and comfort zone. Sticking to such a routine will help me develop discipline, focus, and strength, which are things I really want to build in myself. 
I know it might be tough at first to give up personal time and follow such a structured lifestyle, but I‚Äôm ready for it. I believe this setup will help me stay focused on my inner growth without getting distracted. I‚Äôm prepared to follow the program‚Äôs rules and routines because I trust that this experience will bring about the change I‚Äôm looking for.
column56: I understand that the program will be physically demanding with activities like walking long distances, sitting cross-legged for long periods, and even doing tasks like farming. While it might be challenging at first, I feel ready to take it on. I know that these physical activities are part of the experience, helping to build strength, endurance, and patience. Though it may be tough at times, I‚Äôm willing to push myself and adapt, as I believe these challenges will help me grow both physically and mentally. I see it as a chance to learn to handle discomfort and build resilience.
column57: I‚Äôm fully willing to be assigned to any type of volunteering activity, whether it‚Äôs physically demanding or office-based, for the entire program. I understand that each task, whether it involves hard physical work or something more administrative, has its own value and is an important part of the experience. I‚Äôm ready to give my best, no matter the type of work assigned, as I know that this variety of tasks will help me grow, build resilience, and learn new skills. I see this as a chance to be fully involved, learn from every experience, and contribute wherever I‚Äôm needed.
column58: I‚Äôm comfortable with the idea of sharing my space with other volunteers, including staying in a dormitory, using shared bathrooms, and working closely during volunteer activities. I believe that sharing these spaces will help me learn to adapt, become more patient, and build a sense of community. It‚Äôs a chance to connect with others on a similar journey, learn from them, and support each other. While it may require adjusting to a new level of simplicity, I see this as part of the growth process and am ready to embrace it as part of the experience.
column59: My family is supportive of my decision to stay at the Isha Yoga Center for the entire program. They understand that I‚Äôm seeking personal growth and inner transformation, and they believe that this experience will be beneficial for me. While they‚Äôll miss having me around, they appreciate the purpose behind this journey and are encouraging me to fully commit to the program without distractions. Their support gives me confidence to dive into the experience wholeheartedly.
