column54:
I wish to go through Sadhanapada at this particular time because I‚Äôve experienced profound personal transformation through my Inner Engineering program and the practice of Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya over the last seven months. Having overcome fears that previously disrupted my sleep and thoughts, I now feel a renewed sense of clarity and inner peace. 
 
At 25 years old, I see this as a pivotal moment in my life where I can build a strong foundation for my future. Through Sadhanapada, I hope to deepen my spiritual practice and integrate the lessons I've learned. I want to cultivate greater mindfulness and enhance my ability to stay grounded amidst life's challenges. 
 
Being part of a community of like-minded individuals will not only provide support and encouragement but also inspire me to stay committed to my journey. This age is an important time for personal and spiritual growth, and I want to make the most of it. 
 
Ultimately, I aim to explore new dimensions of my practice, strengthen my connection to myself, and develop a more profound sense of purpose and commitment in my daily life. Sadhanapada feels like the perfect opportunity to continue this positive momentum and grow even further on my spiritual path.
column55:
I recognize that following the strict daily schedule and having very little personal time will be a significant adjustment. However, I see this structure as essential for deepening my practice and fostering discipline. While it may feel intense at times, I believe that the focused environment will help me stay committed to my goals and enhance my spiritual growth Also now i have a work schedule of almost 12 hours a day so dedication and unwavering attitude will help me focus.But i will leave all my work and come to give my 100% on my sadhana. 
Although personal time may be limited, the experiences I gain through sadhana and community involvement will be enriching and fulfilling. Ultimately, I believe this structured approach will help me cultivate a deeper connection with myself and the practices I am committed to.
column56:
I feel ready to embrace the physical demands of the program. Over the past seven months, my daily practice of Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya has already helped me build a sense of discipline and inner strength. While walking long distances, sitting cross-legged for extended periods, and engaging in physically demanding activities like farming may be challenging, I see them as valuable opportunities to push my limits and grow both physically and mentally. 
 
I understand that these activities are an integral part of the Sadhanapada experience, designed not just to test the body but to cultivate endurance, presence, and mindfulness. I‚Äôm confident that with the right attitude and willingness to adapt, I‚Äôll be able to meet these challenges and find joy in them as part of my spiritual journey.
column57:
I am fully willing to take on any kind of volunteering activity assigned to me, whether it is physically intense or office-based, for the full duration of the program. I understand that each task, no matter how challenging or routine, is an essential part of the overall Sadhanapada experience, contributing to my growth and the collective purpose of the program. 
 
I see these activities as opportunities to cultivate discipline, humility, and a sense of service. Whether working on the field or performing office duties, I am committed to approaching each task with dedication, mindfulness, and an open heart. I believe that engaging fully in any role assigned to me will help deepen my practice and allow me to contribute meaningfully to the community.
column58:
Having already lived away from home since the age of 19, and experienced sharing space with roommates during both your education and job, I don‚Äôt see communal living as a hindrance for me. In fact, those past experiences have likely strengthened my ability to adapt to new environments, work well with others, and maintain a sense of personal balance even in shared spaces. 
 
I‚Äôve learned how to coexist respectfully with others, manage shared facilities, and create a comfortable living environment despite potential challenges. These experiences have prepared me to embrace the dormitory stay, shared bathrooms, and collaborative volunteering activities during Sadhanapada with ease and openness. I look forward to the sense of community that comes from living and working closely with others, knowing that it will further enrich my journey.
column59: My family is supportive of my decision to stay at the Isha Yoga Center for the full duration of the Sadhanapada program. They understand that this is a significant step in my personal and spiritual growth. Over the years, they have seen the positive changes in me through my practices and how my commitment to Inner Engineering and Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya has brought more clarity, peace, and focus into my life.
column60: At this point, I don‚Äôt have any additional questions about the program. Everything was clearly explained during the webinar, and I feel well-informed and ready for the experience. If anything does come up later, I‚Äôm confident I‚Äôll be able to seek guidance or clarification when needed.

They also said it is a once in a lifetime opportunity, and even if I was successful with Poornanga, I may not be able to do Sadhanapada afterwards. I was very impressed by people who did Sadhanapada, and I know quite a few people in this current 2024/2025 batch and they told me it has been very worthwhile. I have wanted to do Sadhanapada before but the timing is really good this year as I have intentionally kept it that I will be free from late May/early June. To be very honest, I have been wanting to go through Sadhanapada for a long time, since 2 years now! The moment I found out there‚Äôs a program like this via YouTube‚Äôs recommendation, I was like I have to go through this anyhow. I had just began following Sadhguru at that time and was in 11th grade so didn‚Äôt know much about Isha Yoga Programs then.. After researching I found out IE completion & initiation was required for it then after almost two years later I got initiated just so that I can be part of this program. 
Now is the time as I finished high school & currently in a gap year hence I wish to go through it at this particular time. 
 
 
I am looking forward to grow in numerous ways through the program. In every way possible, I want to invest my time upon self transformation on the level of body, mind, emotion & energy. I hope to be balanced, strong, flexible, & fit, establish mental clarity as a student & seeker. I wanna have emotional stability & learn how to use thoughts & emotions, enhance my perception of life, deepen my sadhana in a powerfully consecrated space along with dedicated & focused Sanghas. Not only that but also lead an intense & energetic yogic life, empower myself to be friction free in the world & drop all my nonsense focusing on my inner growth through the program.
column55: We are there for a reason and a certain purpose so I completely agree with and respect the norms & guidelines of staying in the Ashram. column57: I‚Äôm coming there with a certain commitment to grow and transform my self so I‚Äôm willing 100% to do any kind of volunteering activity to the best of my ability no matter if they may physically intense, demanding or office based, for the full duration of the program because that is what I‚Äôm there for after all - to break my limitations!

column54: I‚Äôm eager to go through Sadhanapada at this particular time because I feel a strong desire to deepen my self-awareness and cultivate a more disciplined approach to my personal growth. I believe that the structured environment and community support offered by the program will help me confront my habits and patterns more openly. My hope is to develop a greater sense of mindfulness and resilience, allowing me to navigate challenges with clarity and intention.
column55: While the experience can be mentally and physically grueling, it offers the opportunity for profound inner transformation. By surrendering to the discipline and structure, participants often come out of the program with a deep sense of peace, clarity, and purpose.
column56: Though difficult, these physical tasks often lead to a stronger connection between body and mind. The body becomes more attuned to endurance, and the mind learns to push through discomfort. Over time, these challenges usually transform into strengths, with participants finding physical practices more manageable as they progress through the program
column57: Ultimately, volunteering, no matter the form, is an integral part of personal and spiritual growth. Accepting any task with willingness and dedication will deepen the impact of the program.
column58: Overall, while sharing space with many other volunteers can be challenging, it‚Äôs a key aspect of the Sadhanapada program‚Äôs focus on selflessness, community, and spiritual growth. By embracing it with a positive and open attitude, the discomfort of shared living can become a valuable tool for personal transformation.
column59: They are deeply supportive, especially they understand the spiritual and personal growth potential of the program. They will see it as a valuable opportunity for transformation and self-discovery, and encourage loved one to embrace the experience fully.

Basically, if he clears his CA then only he would be able to come for SP.

He mentioned that his parents have been waiting for him to start earning. Also, he mentioned that the money he earned from his internship & stock market, he has kept it for his family as savings for them.

column54:
1.Most of my time till now i have spent is on education. One thing that keeps bothering me is, i have somehow pulled myself out of many challenging situations without using 100% ability. It's because i lack discipline and consistency. It's always been on and off with me. I've always wondered what i would be like if i am disciplined and consistent about something. When i heard of sadhanapda and the intensity of the program, the schedule, i thought this would be the best opportunity to test myself. 
2. I'm a CA aspirant. Past 3 to 5 years of this CA journey wasn't easy for me physically and mentally, keeping upto long hours of studies and work. Especially the internship part. I felt so frustrated, irritated and helpless at times. This also resulted in me being angry, frustrated towards people around me. I have failed in handling myself in many situations which i hate the most. 
This was because of lack of clarity and balance within myself and i never want myself to be in such situations. I choose Sadhanapadha so that i can work on myself to attain that clarity and balance within myself so that i could conduct myself and function at my best. 
3. Another aspect is, past few years i have grown physically weak as a result of lack of physical activity. I find a bit challenging to have mental clarity without physical balance. So when i checked about sadhanapada, i had all the reasons to apply for it.
column55: To be honest, that is one of the main reason which pulled me towards sadhanapada. I know it takes lot of efforts to stick to that schedule, which will test me on various levels and that's exactly what i want myself to go through.
column56: Being habituated to long sitting hours without much physical activity at all makes the physical part more challenging. But yes I'm 100% willing to try meet those demands of the program.
column57: I've struggled in past to accepting and adapting to things that i don't like coming my way. That's one of the things i want to change in myself, to learn to use anything that comes my way to grow , to use it to my advantage. I think the seva aspect would help me to achieve that. So I'm willing to do any activity to the best of my ability.
column58: I never liked sharing stay area or bathrooms with people. But the intention of getting enrolled to sadhanapada is to break my boundaries, adapt to new things and still maintain the quality of who i am. So I'm willing to adapt with the facilities provided by isha yoga centre.

column54:
Why Sadhanapada at this particular time? 
 
At this stage in my life, I‚Äôm looking for a profound inner transformation that goes beyond just career success or external accomplishments. Sadhanapada offers a unique opportunity for me to deeply reflect, build emotional stability, and establish a sense of balance that I feel has been missing. I want to cultivate a mind that‚Äôs clear and resilient, capable of handling both life‚Äôs highs and lows with equanimity. 
 
 
What way(s) are you hoping to grow through the program? 
 
I hope to deepen my spiritual experience and immersing myself in a consecrated space where I can focus on my inner development. I‚Äôm really looking forward to volunteering as my previous experience as a Linga Sevak really brought a sense of fulfillment and purpose and deepened my ife experince. Sadhanapada would personally allows me to explore living an ascetic life and develop a stronger foundation in self-awareness to life's face challenges with grace and clarity.

column54:
I started my inner journey with my guru, Sadhguru, back in 2019. My yoga practices became organised and daily from November 2022 when I attended Suriya Kriya programme, and now it's time to take a step furthur in this inner journey.

I want to stretch myself to the maximum and beyond I want to be uncomfortable and challenge myself and go through that consciously and gracefully and I feel like this is the right time for me to join sadhanapada as when I reflect upon my life I can clearly see that it has been falling together to allow this for me, being alive during Sadhgurus era and everything that I went through throughout my life makes me confident that I am meant to be on this spiritual path and it is my time now to enhance it and take solid steps towards it. I hope that through the program I will be able to grow mentally and spiritually I hope and I'm actually confident that I will come out of this program a totally different being I will be more conscious, more inclusive, more confident and committed even more towards my spiritual growth and towards being a walking temple as Sadhguru wants us to be

column47: Linga Seva is a profound and immersive spiritual experience at Dhyanlinga. In it my day began at 3.30 am, ensuring that we were at Dhyanlinga by 4.30 am. The seva involved a variety of activities, from morning cleaning in and around Dhyanlinga to attending the Guru Pooja led by Swami. Throughout the day, I participated in guiding visitors, helping maintain the silence within the Dhyanlinga, and offering seva at the offering counter. We were responsible for maintaining the silence of the space while supporting thousands of visitors in experiencing the transformative power of Dhyanlinga. The day concluded with cleaning the Dhyanlinga. Also at Sandhyakalas there was Nada aradhana in which I also got a chance to play music bowl. This experience allowed me to transcend physical as well as mental limitations, in the powerful presence of Dhyanlinga.
column54:
Namaskaram üôè, 
Currently I am in the last year of Bachelors degree in Mechanical Engineering and by next year April -May, i will complete my degree. So after this completion , I feel the most crucial thing which is needed to be happen is Sadhanapada , as sharings from Annas and Akkas in Linga seva gave me glimpse of what it means to be in ashram and in presence of Sadhguru. So the Only thing which I feel can really make me set right for anything and everything which can take place in this tenure of life and make best out of it is Sadhanapada . And also it can be a tool to deepen clarity.
column55: This year I got a chance to volunteer for linga seva and it was an most influential experience, the 10 days totally changed everything about me , I was with total new sense of life . column56: Even it sounds hard , but I have applied for Sadhanapada to break all limitations so this things are must . And I believe this all activities will happen with ease with Sadhgurus grace.

column58: It's family-like, as Annas and Akkas share not only living spaces but also experiences and they guide if anything is done in a wrong way . And also they motivate in many ways. So it's an amazing experience being with them.
column59:
Namaskaram üôè 
Currently, my family has some concerns about me staying at the Isha Yoga Center for the full duration of Sadhanapada. Their hesitation comes from the significant changes they noticed in me after I returned from Linga Seva‚Äîmy eating habits, daily routine, and behavior shifted so much that they fear I may not return to the same lifestyle or even come back home. I understand that these concerns arise from their love and care, and it‚Äôs natural for them to feel this way. 
 
However, after witnessing the positive transformation in me, both my parents and some of our neighbors were inspired to take the Inner Engineering program offline. I believe that as they deepen their own practices through Shambhavi Mahamudra, they will gradually understand the immense value of Sadhanapada. Following Sadhguru‚Äôs guidance, I have also made it a point to express more love and care towards my parents, which is already fostering greater understanding and harmony. 
 
I am confident that over time they will appreciate why this program is essential for me. And if not right away, I trust that when they see the deeper transformation in me after completing Sadhanapada, their perspective will naturally shift. My focus is to remain fully involved in the process and to keep nurturing our bond with love, allowing it to dissolve any lingering concerns.

column54: I think some of the reasons such as soaking oneself in the high energy of the ashram, further deepening any isha yoga practices in the consecrated spaces of the ashram and being in Sadhguru's presence are common to all of those eager to enter the the Sadhanapada program (myself included) but the main unique reason for joining the program that I think everybody has it individually which it also differs from person to person , for me at least it is because of the challenge that it represents. In my past experiences the biggest breakthroughs I had were when through perseverance and discipline I managed to cross some limits and barriers that for a long time I was unaware of, thus the very high level of difficulty that the Sadhanapada program inherently has is in itself the very aspect I am looking forward to and I have no doubt that it will support my path of becoming a truly human being especially in these phenomenal years that we live in when we have the support of sun itself (due to the solar flares).

column54:
Since discovering Sadhguru, my life has transformed completely. I am more resilient, joyful, and balanced. At times, I experience what could be described as a state of grace, where I perceive life from an entirely new dimension. However, these moments are fleeting, lasting only a day or two. I deeply desire a stronger, lasting balance that allows me to access this state, regardless of my circumstances, and I believe Sadhanapada is exactly what I need to achieve this. 
 
This feels like the perfect time for me, both externally and internally. Externally, I have my family‚Äôs support, and while it was initially challenging, my girlfriend now stands by my decision. I am not yet tied down by my own family, and my job understands that this journey is my priority‚ÄîI‚Äôve made it clear that if accepted, I will go. Internally, I feel prepared: I have been dedicated to the Isha practices, feel more connected, and am certain this is my path. I know within myself that this is the right step forward.
column55: This isn‚Äôt my first Isha program, so I understand that while it may be physically challenging at first, devotion to the process is essential. I‚Äôm fully prepared and more than willing to embrace it.
column56: I‚Äôm in good shape and stay physically active, and I‚Äôm already preparing myself for the journey. Although I haven‚Äôt been accepted yet, I‚Äôm genuinely excited and ready for this experience.

column54:
I want to go through Sadhanapada, as it has been an intense longing within me. Before I knew about IE, I had known about SP, I was never fond of these things. Why people do go through these programs? Why do people want to live like monks, heck why do they even want to become like monks? Everybody is running towards something, is it money, power or popularity - I thought this was it! 
 
I was completely wrong. After IE, many aspects about me changed and I had the longing to intensify my being, without being attached to other accessories in life. I just recently finished my studies and this right now is the best time to give myself, just to myself and nothing else - growing my facilties to the maximum, before I offer myself to the world. I want to break myself, my limitations, my perceptions, everything I think to know. Just experiencing Sangha, Sadhana and Sadhguru.

column36: Applicant was working in the IT industry for a while but has left his job. He is currently a priest in a local Hanuman Temple (Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple) and he has two other people in the temple. He mentioned they would be able to manage the temple when he's away.

Applicant has Volunteered and stayed in the ashram for close to a month and is aware of the food, clothing etc. He is looking forward to the schedule and living in the ashram and wants to live in a consecrated space under Guru's fold.

After graduating his BCA in 2020, He started working with Infosys as a Operation Executive and after a year got promoted as a Team lead. He has 6 people under him and after a year as a Team led he quit Infosys. He mentioned he had rotational night shifts, that interfered with his health, sleep and sadhana and decided to quit. He then was preparing for Exams for a while and then felt he was wasting time and wanted to live a Sadhaka life. So he started helping out in the temple and is now one the priests there where he gets some income as well. 

He has learnt Karate and has gone for some competitions (but did not give the exam/test for any belt). He's also learning 7-8 months dance (freestyle).

Languages known : English & Hindi : Read, Speak ,Write, Understand
Marwadi : Speak, Understand
He graduated BCA in 2020 and while working for Infosys he also did MCA (distance education) and graduated in 2022.

His Father (aged 52-53) is an electrical contractor and his mother (47-48) is a house wife now. She has a younger sister who is doing BBA First year. She used to be a beautician before. The applicant has been mostly living in the temple and its seems his parents house in 10 kms away. On probing further, he mentioned its not like he left the house. His temple activities might go late and it did not make sense to travel every night just to sleep in the house so he's sleeping in the temple only. He mentioned his father anyways takes care of the electrical work in the temple and his parents visit the temple often and he also visits anytime he wants to see his parents as they live close anyways. In his house they are neutral to him coming for SP, they understand that it will be good as he's anyway visited the ashram for more than a month (so its not new) , but they are worried if he comes for SP, he might stay there and become a monk.
He mentioned his parents are independent even now. And he anywasy has some savings for emergencies for his parents and also himself when he comes for SP.
No Legal concerns

column54:
After spending 3 months as a generally volonteer in the IYC and doing my best to be as involved with the Sadhanas, the Sevas and all the opportunities of this wonderfull space, I needed to return home and evaluate the impact of this incredibly intense experience. I realized that it had changed me quite a lot: it feels that I percieve myself and the world with more clarity, I feel more energetic and my sleep quotas have decresed, my emotions are more steady and I feel more joy out of small occurences, I am doing a few hours of sadhanas daily which I was never able to keep up before, I do not consume any alcohol or other intoxicants... 
After spending 3 months as a generally volunteer in the Isha Yoga Center of Coimbatore (January until April) and doing my best to be as involved with the Sadhanas, the Sevas and all the opportunities of this wonderful space, I needed to return home and evaluate the impact of this incredibly intense experience. I realized that it had changed me quite a lot: it feels that I perceive myself and the world with more clarity, I feel more energetic and my sleep quotas have decreased, my emotions are steadier and I feel more joy out of small occurrences, I am doing a few hours of sadhanas daily which I was never able to keep up before, I do not consume any alcohol or other intoxicants... 
Now, I strongly believe that Sadhanapada will help me go a step further in my spiritual journey and growing towards a more vibrant body, a more joyful mind, a heart full of love and ecstatic energies. With this program, I wish to become more conscious and inclusive, as well as becoming more perceptive and I have the precious and rare opportunity to be completely devoted to the program form July 2025 until May 2026.

He learnt Surya Kriya and Angamardhana last month, he does alternate day each. He came for trial period in May, initial days he felt why he was here and what he was doing, slowly he got used to seva and ashram. He came again for 15days during Navrati he left on Oct17th, His experience of sadhana is different in SuryaKund, he felt he was more flexible there, he was in farm and he enjoyed that activity too. He could not visit Yogeshwara linga as much as other temples, this time when he came to ashram he went to Devi first when they gave initial day off.

He was smiling throughout, happy, spoke everything openly, did not try to hold back on any information. he was same speaking about ashram, volunteering, Navratri time being here. Felt very calm and sat in ardhasiddha asana , came presentable. Travelled so many places - Gujarat, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Ladhakh, Ujjain, 12 jyothirlinga, and many more in the last few years after corona either solo or with friends. He went to Gym for 14months and when he started Shambhavi, his body was not flexible so he stopped gym. During covid when he had to stop his coaching in bengaluru mid way and come back home (hyderabad) as his mother was worried. He was in a low state as he had to drop out of college for cricket and drop out of cricket for family, at that time he used to watch TV, sleep, and play online games, it was very stressful for 4-5months,. then gym helped his alot to get him out of that situation.
None

During his cricket training he used to run for 1hour continuously and not jog in between in 6months. He stopped non-veg in 2023. Eats Rice, sambar, dal, curry millet in brunch and dinner After seeing yellow cycles in Ashram, he's planning to buy a cycle and to strengthen his body. Since he doesn't have much work to do he uses phone for 6hours in a day, didn't find any difficulty in not using phone during volunteering.

column57: I am fully ready. As I said Namaskaram to all the visitors who were entering the Isha Yoga. It had so much impact on me I started looking at people like they are my family. The way the people said Namaskaram to me. That Bhakti towards another human being increased a lot. I would have said Namaskaram to almost 300 to 400 people that day, by the end of the day I was filled with love and joy. I can still feel that day. This happened only because I was willing to do it and to break all my limitations i have. By doing it willingly I gained a lot from it. So, from that day whatever I do, I do it willingly even if I don't really like or whatever it is I do it willingly so I don't struggle while doing the activity.

On many accounts, Sadhguru has mentioned the importance of fixing oneself before entering into the world, that is enhancing oneself on various levels. I see the Sadhanapada program as extremely empowering and since I am graduating this year, 2025 would be the perfect time for Sadhanapada . 
The program would help break my various limitations, say, working beyond fixed timings, doing all sorts of work without discrimination. 
Just living in the ashram would help me dissolving various karmas, and the sangha(company) of spiritually inclined people would help me progress in my spiritual part of my life as well. 
Apart from this Sadhguru has always inspired me in many ways and I always wanted to contribute actively in some way, I feel Sadhanapada would be a stepping stone for this.

column54: At this time in my life, I feel a deep inner calling to immerse myself fully in a space of spiritual growth and self-discovery. Sadhanapada offers a unique opportunity to step away from distractions and focus on aligning myself with higher possibilities. The energy of the program, combined with the disciplined practices, feels like the right environment to deepen my connection with the inner self, cultivate clarity, and live with greater purpose. This is a time for me to surrender to the process and evolve on a spiritual level.
column55: While I recognize that following such a strict daily schedule will be a challenge, I believe it‚Äôs a necessary step for my growth. The rigor of the program aligns with my desire to develop a more disciplined and mindful approach to life. The lack of personal time will push me to confront my inner struggles, which I see as an opportunity for deeper transformation. I am committed to the process and willing to abide by the guidelines, knowing that they are designed to bring out the best in me.
column56: I see the physical demands of the program as a beautiful opportunity to reconnect with my body and nature. Activities like walking long distances, sitting cross-legged, and farming will help me build strength, endurance, and mindfulness. Embracing these challenges with a positive attitude will enhance my discipline and resilience. I believe that engaging in such activities will allow me to deepen my sadhana and contribute meaningfully to the ashram's community while growing physically and spiritually.
column57: I am fully willing to participate in any form of volunteering, whether physically intense or office-based. I believe that seva, or selfless service, is at the heart of spiritual growth. Being involved in any activity, no matter how challenging, is part of surrendering my ego and embracing a life of service. I trust that each task will offer its own unique lessons and opportunities for growth.
column58: Sharing space with others, particularly in a dormitory setting, will be a new experience for me. While it may be uncomfortable at first, I am prepared to embrace the experience as part of my journey towards letting go of attachments and personal preferences. Living in a community setting will teach me valuable lessons about cooperation, humility, and adapting to different circumstances, all of which are essential for inner growth.
column59: My family is understanding and spiritually active, so they are supportive of my decision to participate in Sadhanapada. They recognize the importance of this experience for my spiritual growth and overall well-being, and they encourage me to pursue this opportunity for deeper transformation.
column60: I‚Äôm curious about how the spiritual teachings are integrated into the daily routine and look forward to deepening my experience through the practices.

column54: For much of my life I have gone through the steps of "having, doing and being". After reading "Karma" I have realized my path should be "being, doing, and having." My life to this point has been about achievements and goals - medical school, residency, fellowship, board certification, professorship, being in a "perfect" relationship, climbing mountains, performing in dance teams. Now that my long term relationship has ended I have started to question who and what I am in life. If I am no longer a future wife of my former partner then I started to question the other labels I have created - hiker, dancer, doctor, professor, daughter, sister. Realizing they will all too come to an end at some point in time, it leaves me with more questions than answers as to why I am here and what this life is truly about. I would like to start from the beginning and focus on "being" human. If I understand myself better and have a sense of fulfillment within, then my "doing" (interaction) with others is a natural byproduct and then the "having" is a natural second byproduct of that. If those "labels" I have created for myself (dancer, hiker, doctor, professor, etc) come to an end, then I will still be a whole person because I have focused on the "being" aspect. Sadhanapada would give me the dedicated and focused time to go inward and focus on "being", leaving the labels behind and blossoming from within. With this period of introspection I could then return to my medical school, hospital, friends/family with more joy, peace and creativity. It would in turn affect those around me - students, patients, friends/family. Life should be an expression of your happiness and not a pursuit of it. Sadhanapada will be the first step in finding my happiness within.
column55: I look forward to the strict daily schedule within the ashram. Having no "days off" means you are continually striving for something greater that will transform you.
